web_summary: Stud farm workers: young Vasily Govorukhin and elderly Konstantin Sergeevich Voronov are nursing a newborn foal Buyan, from Bunchuk and Yasnaya, his mother died at birth. The foal, getting to its feet, goes out into the yard and clings to the approaching donkey.

Kuban Cossacks (Kubans), Kuban Cossack Army - part of the Cossacks of the Russian Empire in the North Caucasus, inhabiting the territories of the modern Krasnodar Territory, the western part of the Stavropol Territory, the south of the Rostov Region, as well as Adygea and Karachay-Cherkessia, mainly descendants of people from the Cossack Army Zaporozhye. The military headquarters is the city of Ekaterinodar (now Krasnodar).

“The Fall of Berlin” is a Soviet two-part feature film; film epic staged in 1949 by Mikhail Chiaureli based on the script by Pyotr Pavlenko. Filming took place in the USSR, Prague and at the former UFA film studio in Babelsberg.

“They Have a Homeland” is a Soviet feature film filmed at the Moscow Film Studio named after. Gorky by Alexander Faintzimmer and Vladimir Legoshin in 1949 based on the play “I Want to Go Home” by Sergei Mikhalkov.

Child of the Danube (German: Kind der Donau) is a 1950 Austrian musical film directed by Georg Jacoby and starring Marika Rökk, Fred Liewehr and Harry Fuß. It was one of a cycle of popular musicals made by Jacoby and Rökk.

“Conspiracy of the Doomed” is a Soviet feature film by Mikhail Kalatozov, based on the play of the same name by Nikolai Virta at the Mosfilm film studio in 1950. US Ambassador McHill, in an effort to turn an independent state into the “49th state of America,” becomes the inspirer, organizer and center of a group of conspirators, which includes a number of high-ranking officials and public figures - Minister of Food Christina Padera, Minister of Industry and leader of the Catholic Party Hugo Vastis, leader of the Social Democrats, Minister of Public Security, and subsequently Chairman of Parliament Joachim Pino, as well as Vatican agent Cardinal Birnch and agent of imperialism, a journalist from Chicago Kira Rachel.

1945, Germany. On the eve of the collapse of the Reich, the Nazis are conducting secret negotiations with the Anglo-Americans about the surrender of German troops in the West. Soviet intelligence officers are doing everything possible to expose and disrupt these negotiations.

Colbert (who, by the way, could not have been at Louis’s court at that time) decides to hide the birth of his second son from everyone, including his father, in order to avoid civil war.

“Three Meetings” is a 1948 film made up of three short stories by directors Alexander Ptushko, Vsevolod Pudovkin and Sergei Yutkevich and released only in 1950. The film consists of short stories about participants in the Great Patriotic War, fellow soldiers who returned from the front and entered peaceful life.

Clochemerle is a 1948 French comedy film directed by Pierre Chenal and starring Félix Oudart, Saturnin Fabre and Jean Brochard. It is an adaptation of the 1934 novel Clochemerle by Gabriel Chevallier.
“Vienna Girls” (German: Wiener Mädeln) is a historical musical film directed by Willi Forst, filmed in 1945. Forst himself starred in the title role of composer Karl Zierer.

Love of a Clown, or Pagliacci, is a 1948 Italian film based on Ruggero Leoncavallo's opera Pagliacci, directed by Mario Costa. The film stars Tito Gobbi and Gina Lollobrigida. It recounts the tragedy of Canio, the lead clown (or pagliaccio in Italian) in a commedia dell'arte troupe, his wife Nedda, and her lover, Silvio. When Nedda spurns the advances of Tonio, another player in the troupe, he tells Canio about Nedda's betrayal. In a jealous rage Canio murders both Nedda and Silvio. The only actor in the who also sang his role was the celebrated Italian baritone, Tito Gobbi, but the film is largely very faithful to its source material, presenting the opera nearly complete. The film premiered on 16 April 1950 in the USA. It is notable for having been filmed largely in outdoor settings, much like a big-budgeted film version of a Broadway musical

The Marriage of Figaro (German: Figaros Hochzeit) is a 1949 East German musical film directed by Georg Wildhagen and starring Angelika Hauff, Willi Domgraf-Fassbaender and Sabine Peters. It was based on the opera The Marriage of Figaro by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and Lorenzo Da Ponte, which was itself based on the play The Marriage of Figaro by Pierre Beaumarchais
Modest Petrovich Mussorgsky (March 9, 1839, Karevo village, Pskov province - March 16, 1881, St. Petersburg) - Russian composer, member of the “Mighty Handful”.
Woman Gets a Start is also a 1949 Hungarian drama film directed by Imre Jeney and starring Klári Tolnay, Ferenc Ladányi and Lajos Básti. It was shot at the Hunnia Studios in Budapest.

Where to watch JustWatch Kalin The Eagle 1950 Kalin Orelt Directed by Boris Borozanov Synopsis Constantinople, 1883. During an outing to the Black Island Edith, the adopted daughter of the French ambassador, is saved by Kalin the Eagle.

Rotation is a 1949 East German drama film directed by Wolfgang Staudte and starring Paul Esser, Irene Korb and Werner Peters. It was produced under the auspices of the DEFA film studio in East Germany. It began filming on 29 September 1948 and premiered in theaters on 16 September 1949. The film opens to scenes of Berlin during World War II, with the ongoing war depicted by bombs and explosions, both onscreen and in the background soundtrack. The film then jumps twenty years in time, and, through a of vignettes about worker Hans Behnke, traces the way in which a typical worker who opposes Nazi Party ideology could be drawn into complying and cooperating with the Nazi regime. Significant vignettes include depictions of the high unemployment in 1920s Germany and later, the threat to Hans's job due to his failure to belong to the Nazi party. It is implied that Hans's complicity with the Nazi regime rises out of a desire to be able to provide for his family and not return to the ranks of the Arbeitslos (unemployed). Hans ultimately does join the Nazi party, but still signs of disagreement with their ideology. He eventually aids a resistance group in printing anti-war propaganda, and is finally turned in to the authorities by his son Helmut. Hans is then put in jail, and the timeline returns to that given at the very beginning of the film. Hans is eventually freed from jail, but his wife, Charlotte, has been killed in the war

“Zhukovsky” is a 1950 Soviet color feature film-biography about the “father of Russian aviation” N. At the V International Film Festival in Karlovy Vary (1950), the film was awarded a prize for outstanding direction.
The Council of the Gods - Dii Consentes (also Dii Complices) - a mythological council in the pantheon of Ancient Rome. It consisted of twelve main deities: six gods and six goddesses.

Der Auftrag Höglers (English-language title: Hoegler's Mission) is a German Democratic Republic fantasy movie directed by Gustav von Wangenheim. Högler, the former director of a steel plant now in East Germany, is a rich and ruthless capitalist residing in West Germany.
Soviet professor Lavrov - an experimenter, scientist-breeder, student and follower of I. Michurin, a supporter of Michurin agrobiology and a champion of the theory of T.

The Blue Swords (German: Die blauen Schwerter) is a 1949 East German historical drama film directed by Wolfgang Schleif and starring Hans Quest, Ilse Steppat and Alexander Engel. It sold more than 3,299,432 tickets.

Far from Moscow" is a Soviet feature film directed by Alexander Stolper, based on the book of the same name by Vasily Azhaev in 1950 at the Mosfilm film studio. The film was released on December 19, 1950. A team of construction workers is laying an oil pipeline in the Far East. But some of the workers feel that their place is at the front, and not in the distant rear, many thousands of kilometers from the line of fire. This is what the young engineer Kovshov thinks. The head of the construction site, Rogov, is also eager to go to the front. A conversation with construction manager Batmanov and party organizer Zalkind forces Kovshov and Rogov to reconsider their point of view and realize the importance of their work. Having witnessed the enormous enthusiasm of the Soviet people, they are convinced with their own eyes that the same front is here. taiga winter, using the innovative proposals of the builders, the team lays an oil pipeline in record time. Filming began at the end of 1949. In the spring of 1950, major acting scenes were filmed in Khibiny (On Sakhalin in the working village of Vostochny). Zilbershtein

The Entrapment" (also "Collapse"; Japanese: おとし穴) is a 1962 Japanese black-and-white feature film, the first feature film by Hiroshi Teshigahara, previously known as a documentarian. Combines elements of social drama, telling about the hard life of miners and contradictions in the miners' unions, with a mystical plot about a murder investigation. The film marked the beginning of the director's collaboration with avant-garde composer Toru Takemitsu and writer Kobo Abe, who wrote the screenplay based on his own absurdist play. Subsequently, Teshigahara made three more, based on the novels of Kobo Abe: “The Woman in the Sands” (1964), “Alien Face” (1966) and “The Burnt Map” (1968). based on Kobo Abe (along with Woman in the Sand and The Face of an Alien), several short , and a documentary about the director-writer's collaboration

Tarzan Escapes is a 1936 Tarzan film based on the character created by Edgar Rice Burroughs. It was the third in the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Tarzan series to feature Johnny Weissmuller as the "King of the Apes".

Tarzan's New York Adventure (also known as Tarzan Against the World) is a 1942 American adventure film from Metro Goldwyn Mayer, produced by Frederick Stephani, directed by Richard Thorpe, that stars Johnny Weissmuller and Maureen O'Sullivan. This was the sixth and final film in MGM's Tarzan series and was the studio's last Tarzan feature until 1957's Tarzan and the Lost Safari.

is a 1939 Tarzan film based on the character created by Edgar Rice Burroughs. The Commander of the Ship” is a 1954 Soviet feature film filmed at the Kyiv Film Studio by director Vladimir Brown based on the novel “In a Distant Harbor” by L. M. Zaitsev and G. M. Skulsky. A war veteran and newly minted graduate of the naval academy, captain of the third rank, Vysotin becomes the commander of the destroyer “Derzhavny”, having received it from his teacher, captain of the second rank Zolotov, who was transferred to headquarters. The command sets the task of bringing the Derzhavny into the ranks of the leading ships in the shortest possible time. Vysotin also learns with bitterness that his beloved woman Tatyana married the commander of the guards destroyer “Daring” Svetov. Vysotin gets to work. He decides to focus on increasing the ship's combat effectiveness and involving the entire in this process. With the help of political officer Paramonov, he overcomes difficulties by resorting to unexpected measures. For example, he orders the to lead the ship through the little-known Southern Strait, and the ship's doctor to command the landing force. Svetov laughs at his measures and believes that the main thing is the iron unity of command of the commander

Boris Fedorovich Godunov (monastic name Bogolep; August 2, 1552 - April 13, 1605) - boyar, brother-in-law of Tsar Fedor I Ivanovich, in 1585-1598 the de facto ruler of the Russian kingdom, from February 17 (27), 1598 to April 13 (23), 1605 - the first Russian Tsar from the Godunov dynasty. Boris Godunov began his career by serving at the court of Ivan the Terrible.

“Carnival Night” is a 1956 Soviet comedy musical film directed by Eldar Ryazanov. This is his first independent feature film released on the big screen, and the third role of Lyudmila Gurchenko.

Mister 420 (Hindi श्री ४२०, Shree 420) is an Indian black and white romantic drama film directed by Raj Kapoor, released on September 6, 1955. The film consists of two parts, the first of which contains elements of burlesque and pure comedy.

“Case No. 306” is a Soviet one-part feature film, shot in 1956 by director Anatoly Rybakov based on the story of the same name by Matvey Roizman. Leader of Soviet film distribution (1956, second place) - 33.5 million viewers.

In many pre-industrial societies and some modern countries with agrarian economies, sons rather than daughters were and still are important because men have higher social status there, as men are physically stronger and perform the tasks of agriculture more efficiently. In China, in order to eliminate rapid population growth, the “One Child Policy” was in effect.

“Captain of the Old Turtle” is a Soviet historical adventure feature film directed by Vsevolod Voronin and Genrikh Gabay, based on the story of the same name by Lev Linkov at the Odessa Film Studio in 1956. The film tells about the fight against the counter-revolutionary underground in the south of the country in the first years of Soviet power, about the service of the first Soviet border guards, the Black Sea, who in the early 1920s had the opportunity to intercept scows with foreign cargo for hidden anti-Soviet fighters.

Shortly after the end of World War II, in the small French town of Cibourg, a policeman responding to shots fired finds a woman with three bullet wounds in house 26 on Rue Dante. The victim turns out to be the famous actress Madeleine Thibault; In the hospital, she regains consciousness and tells the investigator her story.

“A Man is Born” is a Soviet feature film, melodrama directed by Vasily Ordynsky based on the script by Leonid Agranovich. A young girl, Nadezhda Smirnova, comes to Moscow to go to college, but fails the exam.

Since the 19th century, the tradition of a post-wedding journey has emerged in Russian secular society, during which the newlyweds celebrated their wedding. In a figurative sense - the initial time of any joint venture, a business when nothing yet causes worries (jokingly).

The film takes place in the USSR in the 1930s. But the boy, risking his life and being vigilant, exposes his enemies and wants to hand them over to the security officers. Trying to prevent his enemies from escaping, he is wounded

“The Forty-First” is a feature film directed by Grigory Chukhrai, based on the story of the same name by Boris Lavrenev. The second film adaptation of the story after the film by Yakov Protazanov.

A garment factory operates on a continuous basis and also produces defective products, delivering them to a department store. The head of the ready-to-wear section in a department store, Mikhail Ivanovich Krylov, comes into conflict with the director of the clothing factory, Anna Andreevna Andreeva.

“Alien Relatives” is a Soviet full-length black-and-white feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1955 by director Mikhail Schweitzer based on the story “Not for the Court” by V. The plot is based on the conflict between Komsomol member, leading collective farmer Fedor and the parents of his young wife, ardent opponents of collective farm life.

The new chairman of the collective farm, Semyon Frolov, who previously lived here, arrives in the village of Krutiye Gorki. Taking over business from former chairman Gorelov, he discovers the illegal sale of hay.

The plot contained all the makings of an ordinary “production” film with a cliched conflict in those years: the boss is a conservative, his subordinate is an innovator. But the authors did not follow a literary scheme, but rather life itself, and this saved the film.

“The Tragedy of Othello, The Moor of Venice” or briefly “Othello” (eng. The Tragedy of Othello, The Moor of Venice) is a tragedy by William Shakespeare, written around 1603 based on the novella “The Moor of Venice” by Cinzio Giraldi from the collection “Ecatommiti”.

Sailor Chizhik" is a Soviet drama film filmed at the Kyiv Film Studio in 1955. Director and scriptwriter - Vladimir Brown. Premiere on USSR movie screens - January 4, 1956. Based on the story “Nanny" by Konstantin Stanyukovich. Having been wounded during an exercise, sailor Fedos Chizhik (Mikhail Kuznetsov) is sent as an orderly to the house of Captain Luzgin. The captain's wife - a young, beautiful and spoiled woman - treats the orderly very harshly, constantly humiliating him, considering him a serf, a third-class person. The only joy in a sailor’s life is communication with Luzgin’s little son, Barchuk Shura, a kind and sensitive boy. One day, unable to bear the insults of the mistress, the orderly decides to run away from . child. Chizhik looked after him as a vigilant nanny, never leaving Shura for a minute, literally snatching the boy from the clutches of death. Only then did the woman understand how unfair she had been to this spiritually generous and kind man

A young worker at an automobile manufacturing plant, Anton Karnilin, fails to fulfill the production plan due to love troubles with the daughter of the plant manager, Lyusya, quarrels with friends, and starts drinking. The foreman and his adopted daughter Tatyana Olenina, a design engineer at the plant, come to his aid.

Ilya Muromets (full epic name is Ilya Muromets son Ivanovich, there are also variants: Ilya Morovlin, Muravlenin, Murovets, Muromlyan; Ilya the Serpent Fighter) is one of the main characters of the ancient Russian and Russian epic epic. Bogatyr, a peasant son, a native of North-Eastern Rus', who came to serve in Kyiv with Prince Vladimir; led the defense of Ancient Rus'.

Mexicans (Spanish: Mexicanos) are the third largest nation (after the US Americans and Brazilians) in the Western Hemisphere. Mexicans have diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds, but they share a common Latin American background, namely Mexican culture and the Spanish language.

A powerful underwater explosion occurred in Soviet territorial waters of the Pacific Ocean. An employee of the Oceanographic Institute, Denisov, a casual witness to this explosion, notices the unusually rapid growth of lichen on the coastal rocks.

Walking Through Torment” is a Soviet historical drama, a full-length feature film in three parts based on the novel of the same name by Alexei Tolstoy, its first film adaptation. The film is dedicated to the fate of two sisters - Katya and Dasha, against the backdrop of the collapse of the Russian Empire and the Civil War, and their love stories with Roshchin and Telegin, respectively. The film adaptation follows the text of the novel with abbreviations associated with the film format. 1914: a silent scene of Katya’s ride with Bessonov in a cab is shown. This is followed by Dasha’s visit to Telegin’s apartment, an evening of futurists and an acquaintance with Telegin. The episode of Dasha’s fleeting meeting with Telegin in the spring, when she does not notice him. Violets as a gift from Bessonov and Katya’s declaration of love for him. Evening reception at the Smokovnikovs’ and presentation of “Modern Venus”. Telegin witnesses a strike at the factory and the execution of workers. Dasha comes to Bessonov and later reprimands her sister, after which Katya confesses to her husband of cheating. The sisters leave St. Petersburg: Katya goes to Paris, and Dasha takes exams and goes to her father in Samara. On the Volga steamer she meets Telegin again

Old Man Hottabych” is a Soviet feature-length color fairy tale film, produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1956 by director Gennady Kazansky based on the story of the same name by Lazar Lagin. The picture from beginning to end clearly how dangerous it is to be friends with the genie - despite his power and undoubted affection for the boy, Hottabych often becomes the cause of serious problems in Volka’s life and more than once puts him in danger. It often seems that friendship with Hassan has become Volka’s burden. While swimming in the Moscow River, 12-year-old pioneer Volka Kostylkov finds an ancient clay jug covered with algae and brings it . Naively believing that the jug may contain jewelry, which in his dreams he takes to the historical museum, Volka opens the vessel. Thick smoke comes out of it, materializing into an old man with a gray beard, wearing a turban and an oriental robe. Having barely gained freedom, the old man breaks the jug with curses, then bows deeply to Volka and explains that he is Hassan Abdurrahman ibn Hottab, a powerful wizard whom the boy freed from a thousand-year prison. Volka became friends with the genie and began calling him by his patronymic - Hottabych. In gratitude for his salvation, the genie promises the boy to carry out his every order. Together with him, Volka flies to India on a magic carpet to rescue his friend, headman Zhenya, whom the genie sent there in retaliation for Zhenya’s threats to condemn Volka for his insolence to the teacher at a class meeting. On the way , they almost crash and land in a swimming pool near the sanatorium named after Sergo Ordzhonikidze. Upon returning to Moscow, Hottabych's mischief almost caused a tragedy: tired of the roar of the jet engines, he turned them off, which he smugly reported to Volka, to the latter's horror. At the last moment, the pioneer manages to convince Hottabych to start the engines and everything ends well
Night Patrol” is a Soviet feature film filmed in 1957 by director Vladimir Sukhobokov. The Soviet actor and singer Mark Bernes starred in one of the main roles

A film about the unknown heroes of the Great Patriotic War and the struggle of internationalists against fascism. In 1942, Alexey Severin, an officer of the Red Army who was wounded in battle, using the documents of the dying Miroslav, a Czech doctor serving in the German army, avoids capture and, using his certificate, ends up in Slovakia.
Fanfan la Tulipe is a 1952 French comedy adventure film directed by Christian-Jaque. It has also been categorized under swashbuckler films.

The Secret of the Two Oceans” is a Soviet two-part fantasy-adventure film of 1955-1956 directed by Konstantin Pipinashvili based on the novel of the same name by Grigory Adamov. Production of the Order of Lenin film studio "Georgia-Film". In the Atlantic Ocean, the Soviet motor ship Arktika dies under mysterious circumstances. At the same time, the French motor ship Victoire explodes in the Pacific Ocean. The of the newest secret submarine "Pioneer" will have to find out the causes of these disasters. The submarine has fantastic capabilities for its time: unique diving equipment, a bathyscaphe with an airlock chamber for receiving divers, the ability to move underwater at the speed of a courier train, a large diving depth and autonomous , as well as weapons that have no analogues. An enemy of the Soviet Union, a circus aerialist, kills his twin brother, military designer Gorelov, and under his guise infiltrates the submarine, receiving the position of chief ship mechanic. At a predetermined moment, the false Gorelov was going to leave the boat in a spacesuit and destroy it with a time bomb

The main character of the film, Leah, is a girl with a complex character. Working as a driver for various high-ranking officials, she does not recognize authority, which often leads to conflicts. For this she was nicknamed “Thorn”. Leah's passenger is the young architect Georgy, an opponent of excesses in construction. Having fallen in love with George, Leah joins in his struggle with supporters of the old (“Stalinist”) architecture. The script of the film was written specifically for Leila Abashidze after she played the central role in the film “Dragonfly”, and Leah was actually a variation of Marine (Abashidze’s character in “Dragonfly”), which did not escape the attention of critics (at the All-Union Creative Conference of Cinematographers in 1959, using the example of these two, the thesis about the monotony of Georgian film comedy was developed). The film became one of the leaders in Soviet film distribution in 1957 (7th place, 29.3 million viewers), but critical assessments were mixed. Thus, critic G. Fomin, in an article in the magazine “Art of Cinema,” spoke negatively about the work of the director and screenwriter, who did not fully use the possibilities of the musical comedy genre, but praised the songs of the composer S. Tsintsadze and the acting of L. Abashidze. The fact that the film largely owes its success to the central actress was emphasized by film critic S. Rizaev, comparing “Splinter” with the Armenian film “Her Fantasy”, which had a similar script, where such an actress was not found

” - Soviet black and white full-length feature film, based on the play of the same name by Viktor Rozov, directed by Viktor Eisymont at the Gorky Film Studio. Nephew Alexey comes to Moscow from Siberia to stay with Professor Averin’s family during the entrance exams.

“The House Where I Live” is a Soviet feature film filmed at the Moscow Gorky Feature Film Studio in 1957 by directors Lev Kulidzhanov and Yakov Segel. 1935 Two families move into a new house on the outskirts of Moscow, a communal apartment: the Davydovs with three children and newlyweds Dmitry and Lida Kashirin.

“The Cranes Are Flying” is a 1957 Soviet black-and-white feature film directed by Mikhail Kalatozov, based on the play “Forever Living” by Viktor Rozov. Winner of the Palme d'Or at the 1958 Cannes International Film Festival.

Born in Volzhana, raised by a stern and domineering grandmother, Ekaterina was left without a mother at an early age. Rare meetings with her father, an old, honored captain, formed a strong character in her.

A sociable young mechanic moves into a vacant room in a communal apartment and immediately wins the sympathy of the residents. Madame Shpakovskaya, the mother of her only daughter, has her own ideas for a prosperous young man, in whom she recognizes a “celebrity.
The era of the Civil War in Russia: “Yudenich near Petrograd, Denikin nearby” (1919). A strange soldier (Vladimir Kenigson) appears on the train and protects a girl (Margarita Volodina) from robbers.

My Poor Beloved Mother (Spanish: Pobre mi madre querida) is a 1948 Argentine melodrama film of the classical era of Argentine cinema, directed by Homero Manzi and Ralph Pappier and starring Hugo del Carril, Emma Gramatica, and Aída Luz. It was based on a tango of the same name by Pascual Contursi and José Betinotti.

“Pavel Korchagin” is a Soviet color feature film based on Nikolai Ostrovsky’s book “How the Steel Was Tempered,” filmed in 1956, the second film adaptation of this novel. The film takes place in 1920-1930.

“Hostile Whirlwinds” (another name is “Felix Dzerzhinsky”) is a 1953 Soviet feature film. The film is named after the first words of the Russian revolutionary song “Varshavyanka” (“Hostile whirlwinds are blowing over us…”, translation by Krzhizhanovsky).

Petya, an eight-year-old orphan, is given “to be trained” by the German acrobat Karl Becker, who, with abuse and beatings, introduces his new assistant to the circus profession and mercilessly exploits the child in his performances. Commonly cultivated ornamental plants, colloquially called "mallows", usually belong to the genus Alcea, another genus of the same family. “The Street is Full of Surprises” is a Soviet feature-length color film filmed by director Sergei Sidelev at the Lenfilm studio in 1957. Mamluks (also Mamluks, Arabic: مملوك‎ mamluk - “owned”, “slave”, plural مماليك‎ mamelik, from Arabic: مَلِك‎ malik - “owner”) - a military class in medieval Egypt, originally recruited from young slaves of Turkic origin from the Eurasian steppe (mainly Cumans), but then the institution of military slavery quickly spread to representatives of the peoples of the Caucasus (Circassians, Abkhazians, Georgians and Armenians converted to Islam), residents of the Balkans (Albanians, Greeks and others), as well as the southern Slavs and Ruthenians (see Sakaliba). The Mamluks were also recruited from the Egyptians.

1940 Ivanna Stavnichaya, the daughter of the Greek Catholic priest Theodosius, enters Lviv University, which was opened after the establishment of Soviet power. However, the secretary of the admissions committee, a hidden nationalist, tells the girl that she was not accepted because of her “social background.” Ivanna accuses the Soviet regime of injustice, while in fact her fiancé, the fanatical Catholic Roman Gereta, hid from her the truth about the call to study that came from the university. Upset, Ivanna asks for help from Metropolitan Andrei Sheptytsky, head of the Uniate Church in Ukraine, and he advises Ivanna to go to a monastery. The Great Patriotic War begins, the Germans enter Lviv. Ivanna sees how church ministers collaborate with the occupiers, blessing the reprisals against partisans, Jews and civilians. Ivanna’s friend, Yulia, sets the girl up with the partisans. Ivanna joins their squad, but the Uniates find out about this and begin hunting for her. Ivanna's life ends tragically - the German invaders arrest her and, after cruel torture, execute her. ...one of their crimes was connected with the tragic fate of the Ukrainian girl Ivanna. It’s a 1,500 km drive to Moscow, mostly through territory occupied by whites. On the way, Fyodor is arrested by the White Guards, but with the help of friends, as well as a street child and prostitute Marie (Elsa Lezhdey), he manages to escape. Marie and the street kid join the delegates, with Marie saving everyone else at the cost of her life. Only Fyodor and the homeless child make it to Moscow, Mitya and Nastya are killed by the whites. This is an independent, original work of screen, the first attempt to recreate ballet in Tajik cinema. In 1959, the color feature film ballet “Leili and Majnun” was shot for the first time at the Tajikfilm film studio. Stage director G. Valamat-zade made every effort to introduce elements of national folk dance into the fabric of classical ballet as organically as possible. The combination of classics and Tajik dance folklore, the soulful transmission of folk legends through dance with the skillful use of the specific capabilities of cinema is a great achievement of the filmmakers

“The Seventh Voyage Of Sinbad” is an American adventure film-fairy tale about the next journey of the legendary sailor from the book “A Thousand and One Nights”. Produced by Columbia Pictures and directed by Nathan Juran, it was released in 1958.

Soviet intelligence officer Lieutenant Goncharenko, under the name of Baron Heinrich von Goldring, is thrown into the deep German rear with the task of finding out where the secret underground factory is located, which produces new types of weapons. The brave intelligence officer manages not only to obtain all the necessary information, but also to establish contact with the underground and help the famous designer Edward Strong, who was arrested by the Nazis, to escape.
This film is about Soviet border guards who declassified an operation called "Cobra", organized by foreign intelligence. The purpose of this operation is daily photographing of a military facility.

“Resurrection” is a feature film directed by Mikhail Schweitzer, a film adaptation of the novel of the same name by L. N. Tolstoy. The first episode of the film was released on November 20, 1960, the second on March 23, 1962.

Twenty-five thousand communist Semyon Davydov arrives in the village of Gremyachiy Log from Leningrad and begins to carry out collectivization. He is assisted by the chairman of the village council, Andrei Razmetnov, and the secretary of the party cell, Makar Nagulnov. The kulaks and subkulak activists are actively resisting this process. The main enemy of collectivization, Captain Polovtsev, never tires of harming collective farmers. But among the collective farmers there is also a hidden enemy - Yakov Lukich Ostrovnov, who has gained their trust do not immediately realize the advantages of collective farm life, the peasant Kondrat Maydannikov long and painfully tore the umbilical. cord that connected him to the individual farm before he came to the collective farm along with all his property

Normandie-Niémen (ou Normandie - Niemen en russe), est un film franco-soviétique réalisé par Jean Dréville et Damir Viatitch-Berejnykh et sorti en 1960. Ce film retrace de manière romanesque l'épopée du Régiment de chasse Normandie-Niemen. Cette unité de combat est créée en 1942 par le général de Gaulle pour combattre sur le front russe. Une vingtaine de pilotes de l'armée de l'air française, opposants à l'Armistice et aux ordres de Vichy, se rendent en URSS en 1942 pour suivre un entraînement intensif. Une fois formés, ils deviennent d'abord le Groupe de chasse Normandie, qui deviendra plus tard le groupe de chasse Normandie-Niémen, et combattent les Allemands aux côtés des Soviétiques

Young Muscovite Kostya, who has just graduated from school, is sent by Komsomol call to build a new city beyond the Urals and ends up in a team building a high-voltage power line route. The builders around him turn out to be not heroic Komsomol volunteers, but the most ordinary people - various reasons prompted them to radically change their lives and go to the remote taiga, each of them has their own past, sometimes dramatic, sometimes army, sometimes dark.

“The King of Šumavy” (Czech: Král Šumavy) is a Czechoslovak black-and-white feature film filmed by director Karel Kahinya in 1959 at the Barrandov film studio. The film takes place in the summer of 1948 on the section of the Czechoslovak-German border in Šumava and tells the story of Czechoslovak border guards and their struggle with smugglers and refugees who want to leave the country after the communists came to power.

The Queen of Spades” is a Soviet full-length color feature film-opera, staged at the Lenfilm Studio in 1960 by director Roman Tikhomirov based on the opera of the same name by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky. The opera is based on the story of the same name by A. S. Pushkin. At the center of the story is a young engineer Herman, a secretive, strong-willed and passionate person. Ambitious Herman is obsessed with the idea of ​​getting rich. For him there is only work. He rarely attends noble meetings, does not allow himself to drink wine, much less play cards. His friends - officer Tomsky - a merry fellow, a gambler, a spendthrift; rich gambler Chekalinsky, Prince Yeletsky. The latter is engaged to Lisa, a young noblewoman, and is awaiting marriage. Walking in the Summer Garden, German admits to Tomsky that he saw a beautiful girl and fell in love with her, but does not dare to open his feelings

“Prairie Street” (French Rue des prairies) is a feature film co-produced by France and Italy, filmed in 1959 by director Denis de La Pateliere based on the novel of the same name by French actor and writer René Lefèvre. In addition to this title, under which the film was shown at the USSR box office, it is also known as “Meadow Street”.

The Lady with the Dog” is a Soviet feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1960 by director Joseph Kheifitz based on the story of the same name by A.P. Chekhov. Dmitry Dmitrievich Gurov married early, does not love his wife, and is rather burdened by his children. He does not miss the opportunity to have an affair on the side. While on vacation in Yalta, he notices a lady walking along the embankment with her dog. She is young, from good society, married; she is closed and does not meet anyone. Gurov manages to interest the lady, cheer her up and find out that her name is Anna Sergeevna. He thinks there is something “pathetic” about her. A week after they met, they became very . Anna Sergeevna is not like any of Gurov’s women; she is timid, bashful, she is very embarrassed about what happened, she endlessly repeats that now Gurov himself will not respect her. Anna Sergeevna calls herself a bad woman who deceived not her husband, but herself, because she never loved or respected her husband, and compares her husband to a lackey. At first, her naivety irritates Gurov; he is bored. They go to Oreanda and look at the sea. “Gurov thought about how, in essence, if you think about it, everything is beautiful in this world, everything except what we ourselves think and do when we forget about the highest goals of existence, about our human dignity

Evgenia Grande" is a 1960 Soviet drama film directed by Sergei Alekseev based on the Maly Theater performance based on the novel of the same name by Honore de Balzac. The events of the film take place in the French province of the 19th century, in the city of Saumur.. The head of a wealthy family - Felix Grande, a miser and a despot, constantly saves money, does not spend it on anyone or anything, saves on everything. His family's lifestyle suggests limited means and even poverty. However, in fact, Father Grande has long been the richest resident of the city, if not the entire province. The neighbors are vaguely aware of this, observing the respect that Grande shows to the family of the local banker de Grassen and the notary Cruchot. These two parties intend to compete with each other in the fight for the hand of Grande's only daughter and heir - Eugenie, a beautiful and noble girl who suffers from her father's despotism. Suddenly, a new character intervenes in the life of the Grande family and its minions: this is the son of Father Grande’s brother Charles, who came from Paris. The young man's father went bankrupt and, in order to protect Charles from witnessing his father's crash and suicide, sent him to the provinces to live with his uncle.. Papa Grande is absolutely not happy with his nephew (this is an extra expense. ), de Grassins and Cruchot are ready to hate him, because the handsome Charles, a messenger from another world, managed to touch Eugenia’s heart. Under the patronage of his uncle, Charles receives a place in one of the colonies of France, he prepares to leave. Evgeniya promises to wait for him and, as a farewell, gives him all the gold coins that her father gave for his birthday and other holidays.. Charles swears allegiance to Eugenia, he seems to have managed to appreciate this girl, still unaware of how rich her father is. Shortly after Charles's departure, Grandet discovers Eugenie's gold coins. An incredible scandal occurs in Grande's house. But Evgenia steadfastly endures her father’s anger and disfavor.. Unable to withstand the discord in the family, Evgenia’s mother becomes seriously ill. The father, fearing that after the death of her mother, Eugenia may demand a division of the inheritance, forgives her daughter, who meekly signs all the papers, and Grande retains control over all her property. Years go by, Father Grande is getting old, and slowly begins to introduce Evgenia to the course of his operations.. As a result, after the death of the old miser, she becomes the heiress of a huge fortune. She remains faithful to the oath given to Charles, but one day she learns that Charles himself returned to France quite some time ago.. He has changed: he made a good fortune for himself in the slave trade and is going to marry a rich and noble heiress. Eugenie, realizing that for many years she believed in the feelings of a man who turned out to be a “typical Grandet”, selfish and selfish, sends to him the nephew of the notary Cruchot, Monsieur de Bonfon, to settle financial affairs: Charles is still hanging over the debts of his late father, and this could interfere with his marriage. Upon her return with success, she promises her hand to the notary's nephew. Having met with Charles, de Bonfon, during the negotiations, does not deny himself the pleasure of reporting the size of Eugenie’s fortune: about 17 million francs. Charles is shocked, but nothing can be done. Evgenia marries de Bonfon, continues her father's affairs, but unlike him, she does a lot of charity work, has no feelings for her husband and lives separately from him..

The Law is the Law” (French La loi c'est la loi... / Italian La legge è legge...) is a French-Italian film. The world premiere took place on September 17, 1958. All these same adventures that happened in the town of Assola would not have happened in it if it had not been different from others. The border between France and Italy passes through the city, and all life in it is determined by this fact. There are two ways to make money in Assol: either obey the law and be a policeman, or avoid it. Thus, the French customs officer Ferdinand Pastorelli lives in accordance with the first method, and the Italian smuggler Giuseppe La Paglia lives in accordance with the second. And when Ferdinand once again caught Giuseppe, he, unwittingly, turns Ferdinand's life into a complete nightmare. Ferdinand and Giuseppe, whom he detained, come to the tavern, which is a kind of landmark of the town. The fact is that exactly in the middle of the tavern lies the state border between France and Italy. Ferdinand indulges in memories and in a conversation accidentally drops the phrase that he was born in this tavern in the kitchen. This causes an outburst of laughter from Giuseppe, whom Ferdinand has not yet managed to hand over to the authorities for attempting to smuggle contraband. Giuseppe, in order to once again get out and avoid arrest, chokes with laughter and proclaims that Ferdinand is not a Frenchman at all, that he does not even have the right to serve in customs and, therefore, to detain him, since the kitchen where he was born is located in Italy. Considering that Ferdinand's mother is Italian and his father is unknown, it turns out that Ferdinand is an Italian illegally residing in France. A trivial incident leads to Ferdinand being drawn into a cycle of bureaucratic red tape regarding his origins. It is not in vain for Giuseppe, who helps him obtain Italian citizenship. For admitting that he is Italian, Ferdinand is accused of usurpation of identity and loses his family, because the marriage has become illegal, and all his military awards. In Italy they tell him that he is a deserter, although he participated in the war, but on the side of France. He again becomes the husband of his first wife, who after their divorce became Giuseppe's wife, and all the La Paglia children go to him

“Snow Tale” is a 1959 Soviet fairy tale film based on the book “A Tale in Broad Daylight” by Viktor Vitkovich and Grigory Yagdfeld. The second film in the genre of “modern fairy tale” by the director duo Eldar Shengelaya and Alexei Sakharov.

“On the Threshold of Life” (Swedish: Nära livet; also known as “At the Origins of Life”, “Next to Life”) is a film by Swedish director Ingmar Bergman, released in 1958 based on the short stories “Dear, Worthy” and “Unshakable” by Ulla Isaksson from the collection “Aunt Death” (1954). Nur eine Frau ("Only One Woman") is an East German film. It is based on the life of the Leipzig campaigner for women's rights, Louise Otto-Peters, who is portrayed in the film by Karla Runkehl.

Estradasphere was an American experimental rock band that originated in Santa Cruz, California, during the late 1990s. Char Dil Char Rahen (English title: Four Hearts, Four Roads) is a 1959 Hindi film directed by Khwaja Ahmad Abbas, and starring two big stars of the era, real-life brothers Shammi Kapoor and Raj Kapoor. The movie is based on a novel of the same name. Three young men Govinda, Dilwar, and Jhonny waiting at the crossroads for their lovers. Govinda was prevented from marrying Chavi as she is untouchable and driven out of the village. Govinda then waits for her at the crossroads. Dilwar rescues Pyari from Nawab but she refuses to escape without her mother. She then sets up a shop and waits near the crossroad for Dilawar. Jhonny, in love with Stella, is framed by his boss Fereira, and jailed. He later joins the group at the crossroads and starts a garage. Nirmal Kumar the union leader then asks the trio to blast a hill at the crossroad to build a road. {{Music in the film was given by Anil Biswas, with lyrics by Sahir Ludhianvi. A film about the siege of Leningrad, about the dramatic everyday life of 1941 and the spring of 1942. In the center of the film is the fate of a squadron of I-16 fighters from one of the Red Banner Baltic Fleet Air Force regiments under the command of Captain Rassokhin (the role of Mikhail Ulyanov).

Evdokim went through the Civil War. Having returned, he got a job at a factory, where he met Evdokia’s father. Under the guise of playing checkers, Evdokim comes to visit him, where he meets Evdokia. Soon they got married. Evdokim and Evdokia on the outskirts of a provincial town. Soon the first adopted daughter, Natasha, appears. Evdokim works at a factory, Evdokia is a housewife. Then the second child appears, Andrei - Evdokim catches him on the street while stealing. The family, it would seem, is prosperous and happy: the only trouble is that Evdokia cannot forget the love of her youth, Akhmed. Evdokim cannot stand this and offers Evdokia freedom, while he will remain with the children. But all these contradictions are drowned in mutual love for children and each other. Everything is getting better, advice and love are restored in the family, new adopted children appear (Pavel and Katya). Andrey works at a factory, but then all the young people leave the city. Andrei and Natalya also left. Pavel grew up and moved to Leningrad, Katya works at a factory as a telephone operator. All this against the background of Soviet pre-war life, shown slightly romantically, but, in general, correctly. Then the war begins. Just before the war, Evdokia and Evdokim have another child - Alexander - who is left on the doorstep in the cold by his real mother. Both Pavel and Katya leave to fight, but Pavel is killed in the war. Katya returns after it ends. Natalia already has her own family, children. Everyone comes to their parents and rejoices at Katya’s return. She begins to work as a party worker and travel around cities. In one of the cities she meets her future husband, who also turns out to be a party worker, and one day comes with him to a housewarming party at her parents’ house, where all their children and their families have already gathered

“For Two Hares” (Ukrainian: For Two Hares) is a Soviet feature comedy film directed by Viktor Ivanov, released at the Kyiv Dovzhenko Film Studio in 1961. Cossacks (plural from a Turkic word meaning “free, independent person, adventurer, vagabond”) are an ethnic class group of service people (mainly Orthodox Russians and Ukrainians) - members of military formations that performed border service. The descendants of the Cossacks and registered Cossacks formed the basis of the Trans-Danubians in the Ottoman Empire and the Banat Sich in the Austrian Empire, as well as the Bug Cossacks, Azov, Black Sea and Kuban people; to a much lesser extent participated in the formation of the Caucasian lineists, Don, Khoper (including Nekrasovites), Volga, Orenburg, Ural, Siberian and Transbaikal Cossacks in the Russian Empire.

“Clouds over Borsk” is a Soviet feature film on an anti-religious theme directed by Vasily Ordynsky, filmed in 1960 and which became one of the tools of Khrushchev’s anti-religious campaign. The film starred several subsequently famous film actors: Nikita Mikhalkov, Vladimir Ivashov, Inna Churikova, Inna Gulaya, Roman Khomyatov.

Scarlet Sails" is a 1961 Soviet feature film directed by Alexander Ptushko, which became the first full-length sound adaptation of the extravaganza story of the same name by Alexander Green. The role of Assol became the film debut of sixteen-year-old Moscow schoolgirl Anastasia Vertinskaya. The widescreen version was released on June 7, 1961, and the regular version on August 21. The film attracted 22.6 million viewers, becoming one of the leaders in the Soviet box office. In the small seaside village of Kaperne a retired sailor Longren and his young daughter Assol. An old sailor makes toy boats and barely makes ends meet. Despite poverty, Assol grows up to be a very kind, dreamy and pure soul

The script is based on the book “Stronger than an Atom” by Georgy Berezko about soldiers and commanders, their service and life. The heroes of the film are soldiers and officers of the Soviet airborne troops.
In the wealthy noble Popelsky family, the only son Petrik is blind from birth. His mother Anna Mikhailovna, endlessly loving and pitying the boy, raises him like a rare, fragile flower.
Genka Sakhnenko studies at school and works. But he, practically an adult and independent person, has one secret: after work, he climbs into the dovecote.

Dmitry Gorin is an exemplary employee of the Soviet savings bank. He is expecting a promotion - the position of manager of a savings bank branch. When the promotion was already a practically settled issue, Gorin accidentally gives an extra amount to a man who works in the taiga on the construction of the Siberia-Ural power line. The man immediately leaves for Siberia. To regain the money and trust of management, Dmitry has to go to the taiga. However, he is in no hurry to return to Moscow. Shortly before his departure, he, trying to hide a picture from a film magazine that seemed unpleasant to him, uses scraps of various photographs to assemble the image of the ideal girl he dreams of. And it so happens that in Siberia he meets the very beauty who turned out to be in his collage! Gorin says goodbye to his career in the savings bank and becomes a laborer in the team of the man to whom he accidentally gave extra money - Gennady Drobot. Having gone through the difficulties of mastering a new profession, adapting to completely different living conditions, making new friends, Dmitry radically changes his life and wins the heart of the girl of his dreams - foreman Galina Berezka. And, although the voice-over at the end of the film leaves Dmitry Gorin the opportunity to return to the activities of a financier in the future, he emphasizes that for the hero “personal life is forever

The Beggar's Tale” is a story by Georgian writer Ilya Chavchavadze, completed in 1873, about the life of a servant unjustly accused of a crime. Filmed in 1961. In Russian it is known in translations by the brothers Japaridze (“The Robber Gabro”), E. Gogoberidze, Y. Davydov (“The Beggar’s Tale”). The story goes to Chavchavadze’s story “Kako” (or “Kola”), on which he worked since 1858 while still studying in St. Petersburg and which later became the basis for three works - “The Beggar’s Tale”, “Is He a Man?!” and the poem “Several Pictures, or an Incident in the Life of a Robber.” The first edition of the story was completed in 1862, and on February 19, 1863, fragments of the story were published in the Georgian Bulletin magazine under the pseudonym “M. Dzhimsheridze". In March of the same year, Chavchavadze quoted lines from the work (“Reason will enlighten your path, and warm your heart”) in a postcard to Olga Guramishvili

A young teacher, Janis, who has just graduated from a pedagogical institute in Moscow, returns to his native Latgale village of Novye Gudani and begins working at a school. But during his absence the village has changed - everywhere he sees the black cassocks of monks.

“Leon Garros is looking for a friend” (French Vingt mille lieues sur la terre, literally “Twenty thousand leagues on earth”) is a Soviet-French feature film from 1960. During World War II, Frenchman Leon Garros and Boris Vaganov escape from a Nazi concentration camp.

Five Days - Five Nights is a German-Soviet post-war drama by Leo Arnstam (main director), Heinz Thiel and Anatoli Golovanow, which was created in 1961 in collaboration between DEFA and Mosfilm. It deals with the rescue of the paintings from the Dresden Old Masters Picture Gallery shortly after the end of the Second World War.

“Noisy Day” is a 1960 Soviet black-and-white feature film, shot jointly by directors Georgy Natanson and Anatoly Efros at the Mosfilm studio based on the comedy “In Search of Joy” by Viktor Rozov (the work was first published in the magazine “Theater” in 1957). The subject of the film: materialism in Soviet society, conflicts between generations and within a young family.
The film takes place “in a country not indicated on any geographical map. ” After the departure of the German troops, the owner of the port left the city, but after some time he returned.

Elisabeth Reimer provides a rich insight into her own life through this book. In an honest and moving way, she takes us through the stages of her unusual life: – childhood and young years in Hungary – the escape of the large family during the war – mission work in post-war Germany – the real spouse and the new tasks – from foster parents to the children's home – visits to Eastern Europe – an invitation to Canada – the early death of her loved one Life situations are often hopeless, yet Elisabeth Reimer always had a living hope.

Husband for Susy (Hungarian: Rangon alul) is also a 1960 Hungarian drama film directed by Frigyes Bán and starring Mária Sulyok, Imre Ráday and Tibor Bitskey. It was shot at the Hunnia Studios in Budapest.

“Alba Regia” (Hungarian: Alba Regia) is a Hungarian feature film filmed in 1961 by director Mihaly Szemes based on the novel by Béla Levai and Tamás Szypos. Hajnal, who always considered himself outside of politics, falls in love with the Soviet intelligence officer, radio operator Alba, who is operating in Hungary, which was already practically occupied by the Wehrmacht.
“The Tale of Fiery Years” is the first Soviet wide-format feature film, shot in 1960 by Yulia Solntseva. The premiere took place on February 23, 1961 at the Moscow Mir cinema.
Five newly married couples move in a new two-story house. They have everything except family happiness.

Red Army junior lieutenant Ivlev, just graduated from college, arrives for service in Berlin a few days before Germany’s surrender in the Great Patriotic War. In a battle-ravaged city, soldiers find a pregnant German woman, and the unit’s command decides to help her get to the hospital.

The film tells about fishing on the shores of the Caspian Sea. The plot centers on the fate of two bosom friends from childhood - Farman and Assad.

The liberation of Lithuania from the Nazis is underway - the front has already passed, cannonade is still thundering nearby, but peaceful life is already beginning - the peasants of one of the villages decide to start sowing. But what remains is the land of the fist of Sankus, who disappeared from the village as soon as the Germans left, and the approach to the lands of the Stankus is mined.

The Magnificent Seven is a 1960 American feature film, a classic Western by John Sturges, an adaptation of Akira Kurosawa's philosophical drama The Seven Samurai. Oscar nomination for Elmer Bernstein's score.

“The Amphibian Man” is a science fiction novel about a man who can live under water, written by Alexander Belyaev in 1927. He became widely known in the writer’s native country, as did the Soviet film “Amphibian Man,” based on it in 1961, starring Vladimir Korenev and Anastasia Vertinskaya.

“The Hussar Ballad” is a Soviet film comedy filmed at the Mosfilm studio in 1962 by Eldar Ryazanov based on Alexander Gladkov’s play “A Long Time Ago” (1941). The film begins in 1812; The plot is based on the story of seventeen-year-old Shura Azarova, who, dressed in the uniform of a hussar cornet, sets off to defend her homeland➤.

The plot is based on the dramatic fate of the Red Army commander Alexei Ivanovich Pavlov. Having been captured near Mga in January 1942 and finding himself among the displaced persons, the hero did not immediately decide to return to the USSR.

Parisian Mysteries” (French: Les mystères de Paris) is a French film starring Jean Marais. A free adaptation of the novel of the same name by Eugene Sue, which conquered the world in the 1840s. all of Europe. The main character of the film is the Marquis Rodolphe de Sambreuil, played by Jean Marais. He is opposed by the villain Baron de Lansignac. Rodolphe has a friend, Irene, who fluctuates somewhat between the honest, but not fabulously rich Rodolphe and the dishonest Lansignac. One day, while participating in a street carriage race, Rodolphe runs over an old poor man. The poor man turns out to be alive and says that he was not hurt. Rodolphe gives him his wallet with money. Later the poor man dies, and his widow and her young daughter Marie have nothing to on. Marie disappears while looking for work. The evil "Owl" - the owner of a night hangout - is involved in the case. Rodolphe disguises himself as a commoner and goes to the “bottom” of Paris, tries to find and save the girl, getting into various troubles - Lansignac, “The Owl” and their bandit assistants are perpetrating intrigues on him

Three friends - Alexander Zelenin, Vladislav Karpov, Alexey Maksimov - studied together at the Leningrad Medical Institute. At the arranged meeting spot, Nikolai cannot find Zhenya and ends up calling her name. A woman, Zhenya Efremova, responds, and it turns out she has indeed been waiting for Pyotr. Nikolai assumes she is deeply upset by Pyotr’s absence. During their conversation, Nikolai learns that Zhenya works as a postal worker and has lost 300 rubles of government money, which could lead to serious consequences for her. Determined to help, Nikolai spends the day with Zhenya, trying to raise the money through a of unexpected and adventurous methods. Most often, coins are made by minting and are in the shape of a circle cut from a sheet of metal. In ancient times, the methods of minting coins were very simple: from a metal plate flattened by blows of a hammer, a coin circle was cut out with a chisel or, in rare cases, a round steel cylinder with pointed edges, and then a type was stamped on it, placing a steel or brass cylinder on it with the type of coin engraved on its end inside and striking the top of the cylinder with a hammer.

Post restant, sometimes referred to as Post-restant, is a Romanian romantic and social comedy film produced in 1961 and released in 1962, directed by Gheorghe Vitanidis from a screenplay by Octavian Sava. The main roles were played by the actors Iurie Darie, Florentina Mosora, Grigore Vasiliu-Birlic and Ion Dichiseanu. At the beginning of the 1960s, it was the intention of the cinematographic studio "Bucuresti" to produce a film with a strong social theme based on an outline and a finalized script by Octavian Sava, but through the intervention of the director and the General Directo of Cinema, it was balanced and then counterbalanced by the romantic element. This is how the story of an inventive engineer is presented who fights on two levels: the first with the bureaucracy and the conservative attitude of the construction site in the introduction of a new, superior, cheaper and faster construction method of a residential complex; the second with his own problems in his romantic life, when he addresses a woman in correspondence on behalf of her lover and who chooses to meet in reality, but against the ground of shyness presents the more capable flatmate as the author of the letters. The film contains many comical elements of the situation and the human nature of the characters, and in this way the social theme was much reduced, which is why the script editor of the studio and the critics of the time did not consider the film good enough. This is one of the few Romanian cinematographic productions made on Agfacolor film, along with Autumn in the Delta (1951), Ciocârlia (1955), Telegrame and Darclée (1960) and I Don't Want to Get Married (1961

Trajan, Natalitsa's fiancé, goes into the army for three years. A believing girl, at whom her friends laugh because of her belief in God, withdraws into herself and, under the influence of her mother, completely joins the Jehovah's Witness sect. All her joy in life is her younger sister, who finds the Kaloyan doll that Trajan carved for his bride. Trajan, who has returned from the army, tries to “wake up” Natalitsa, sometimes he succeeds, but Natalitsa’s soul is in constant, she is sure that she is a sinner and does not doubt know how to get out of this difficult situation. In the house of Natalitsa’s family there is a secret room in which sectarians hide an underground printing house. The sect is a cover for a spy network created on the territory of Soviet Moldova. Domnika, Natalitsa’s mother, constantly throws Kaloyan out and punishes her youngest daughter for him, because she believes that any doll is idolatry. She is forced to hide him. Because of this, one day she learns about the existence of a secret room and finds herself witnessing a conversation between the “Big Brother” of the sect about the printing house. He, fearing exposure, begins to pursue the girl; she accidentally falls from the attic of the house and dies

“The Kingdom of Crooked Mirrors” is a Soviet full-length color feature film-fairy tale, produced at the Gorky Film Studio in 1963 by director Alexander Rowe based on the story of the same name by writer Vitaly Gubarev. Third-grader pioneer Olya returns home late after school and watching a movie in the cinema, and at the entrance she is frightened by the darkness, where some boys deliberately turn off the lights and jokingly instill fear in her.

The religious belief that the end of the world or human civilization is inevitable and will happen in the near future is called apocalypticism. These beliefs constitute an aspect of eschatology in some religions, a branch of theology concerned with the final events of human history or the ultimate fate of humanity - the collapse of society, the extinction of mankind, etc.

Tobacco (Bulgarian: Tyutyun) is a 1962 Bulgarian drama film written and directed by Nikola Korabov, and based on Dimitar Dimov's 1951 novel of the same name. The film deals with the conflicts and contradictions in Bulgarian society during a period stretching from the early thirties to the end of World War II, and stars Nevena Kokanova as Irina, an aspiring medicine student, and Yordan Matev as Boris, an ambitious man from a working class background.

We, Two Men" is a 1962 Soviet feature film directed by Yuri Lysenko from a script by Anatoly Kuznetsov (based on his story “Yurka - the Pantsless Team”). In the Ukrainian outback, the collective farm driver Mishka Gorlov, who is going to the city to buy a transformer and, at the same time, transporting traders to the market, is similar by a young rural teacher who asks to take her son Yurka to the city to buy him a school suit for the first grade. The rude and scandalous driver reluctantly agrees. On a journey full of unexpected situations and adventures, Mishka with a difficult character and small but independent Yurka quickly find a common language, largely due to the fact that both of them grew up without fathers. And Gorlov begins to rethink his unlucky single life... According to Anatoly Kuznetsov, who really liked the film, “We, Two Men,” along with the official film “Meet Baluev,” were selected for presentation at the Moscow International Film Festival in 1963, but at the last moment in the , without announcing the reason, their film was replaced by “Empty Flight

Stop Station" is a Soviet feature film filmed at the Mosfilm studio in 1963. The last film work of director Boris Barnet (1902-1965). A prominent scientist, academician Pavel Pavlovich (Vasily Merkuryev) takes a vacation. After consulting with doctors, he rejects resorts, sanatoriums and holiday homes, and goes to an ordinary Russian village, where he hopes to change his surroundings, breathe fresh air, engage in his hobby - painting - and take a break from the daily bustle of Moscow. But hopes for peace and tranquility away from big cities are in vain. Having settled in a dilapidated barn, which traditionally accommodates artists who have gotten into the habit of painting local landscapes, Pavel Pavlovich discovers that very interesting and active people in a distant village, serious passions are in full swing and something happens every day. The people are good, local events are both funny and serious, but what is definitely not there is peace

Scaramouche is a 1952 romantic swashbuckler film starring Stewart Granger, Eleanor Parker, Janet Leigh, and Mel Ferrer. Filmed in Technicolor, the MGM production is loosely based on the 1921 novel Scaramouche by Rafael Sabatini as well as the 1923 film version starring Ramon Novarro. It was directed by George Sidney and produced by Carey Wilson from a screenplay by Ronald Millar and George Froeschel. The original music score was composed by Victor Young and the cinematography by Charles Rosher. In France just prior to the French Revolution, Queen Marie Antoinette asks her cousin Noel, the Marquis de Maynes, to uncover the identity of "Marcus Brutus", a dangerous pamphleteer rousing hatred of the aristocracy. She also pressures de Maynes to marry to preserve his line, and at his request for her to choose his bride, he is introduced to Aline de Gavrilac, one of the Queen's wards. Meanwhile, minor nobleman André Moreau kidnaps his beloved Lenore to keep her from marrying another man. After the two decide to get married, Moreau learns that his best man, Philippe de Valmorin, is in hiding for promoting revolution and distributing pamphlets under the allonym Marcus Brutus. Moreau tells de Valmorin to leave Paris, taking Lenore with him. At the same time, Moreau visits his lawyer, Fabien, and forcefully threatens him to disclose the name of his father in order to learn why he has stopped sending an allowance. When Moreau and de Valmorin rendezvous in the woods, it is without Lenore, who, not knowing the identity or motive of de Valmorin, escaped the carriage. They continue on their journey to meet Moreau's father, who is revealed to be the Comte de Gavrillac. Moreau runs into Aline de Gavrillac when her carriage breaks down in the road. They are strongly attracted to each other, but Moreau's ardor suddenly cools when he learns that she is his half-sister. He hides that information from her, partly because of sympathy, when they both enter the House of Gavrillac to see that the Comte has died

Fame is the Spur is a 1947 British drama film directed by Roy Boulting and starring Michael Redgrave, Rosamund John, Bernard Miles, David Tomlinson, Maurice Denham and Kenneth Griffith. It was written by Nigel Balchin based on the 1940 novel Fame Is the Spur by Howard Spring, which was believed to be based on the career of the Labor Party politician Ramsay MacDonald. Its plot involves a British politician who rises to power, abandoning on the way his radical views for more conservative ones. When Hamer Radshaw, a young man from a North country mill town, commits to help the poverty-stricken workers in his area, he takes as his Excalibur a sword passed down to him by his grandfather from the Battle of Peterloo, where it had been used against workers. As an idealistic champion of the oppressed, he rises to power as a Labor M.P., but is seduced by the trappings of power and finds himself the type of politician he originally despised. The Monthly Film Bulletin wrote: "This film is the very polished technique to be expected of its director. It is excellently produced with an essentially north country institution, that of the knocker-up, and north country accents and atmosphere are, for the most part, well sustained where they are needed. Rosamund John gives a very natural performance, and her portrayal of Ann's attitude in the face of death must seem moving even to the most hardened viewer

The events of one day of a young couple expecting the birth of a child. The narrative follows two parallel lines: Slavek goes through an ordinary working day as a TV repairman, while his wife and the future mother of their first child, Ivan, goes to the maternity hospital. Their life together still unfolds in fragments of memories: their first acquaintance on the railway bridge, worries about a rented apartment, a wedding, arrangement of a new apartment. They also remember petty arguments and the fact that they didn't want a child at first. Their dreams and monologues are given. Memories are intertwined with current events in which Slavek is the main character (a debate at school, a conversation with a diplomat, a quarrel at the post office). Alarmed by the anticipation of childbirth, he sensitively and in a new way perceives the things, people and events around him

“Before the Judgment of History” is a Soviet full-length black and white documentary film, filmed by director Friedrich Ermler from the autumn of 1961 to the summer of 1962 and edited at the Lenfilm film studio in 1962-1964. War and Peace (Russian: War and Peace, romanized: Voyna i mir) is a 1965–1967 Soviet epic war drama film co-written and directed by Sergei Bondarchuk, adapted from Leo Tolstoy's 1869 novel. Released in four installations throughout 1965 and 1967, the film starred Bondarchuk in the leading role of Pierre Bezukhov, alongside Vyacheslav Tikhonov and Ludmila Savelyeva, who depicted Prince Andrei Bolkonsky and Natasha Rostova. The film was produced by the Mosfilm studios between 1961 and 1967, with significant support from the Soviet authorities and the Soviet Army which provided hundreds of horses and over ten thousand soldiers as extras. At a cost of 8.29 million Rbls (equal to US$ 9.21 million at 1967 rates, or $60–70 million in 2019, accounting for rouble inflation) it was the most expensive film made in the Soviet Union. Upon its release, it became a success with audiences, selling approximately 135 million tickets in the USSR. War and Peace also won the Grand Prix in the Moscow International Film Festival, the Golden Globe Award for Best Foreign Language Film and the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. Since its release, the film has often been considered the grandest epic film ever made, with many asserting its monumental production to be unrepeatable and unique in film history

Women" is a 1966 Soviet melodrama consisting of three short stories based on the story of the same name by Irina Velembovskaya. One of the leaders in Soviet film distribution in 1966 - 36.6 million people (6th place). Dusya Kuzina comes from the village to the city in the early fifties and accidentally meets a furniture factory worker, Ekaterina Timofeevna Bednova, a widow with a son, who houses her and helps her get a job at the factory. After some time, Dusya begins dating Yurka, known throughout the factory. Their relationship ends with an unsuccessful abortion, and Dusya learns that she will no longer have children. A few years later, the girl Alya (Alevtina) Yagodkina from Dusina’s village wants to leave with Victor, a city guy who came to the village on vacation The mother persuades her daughter and Victor to formalize their relationship first Victor agrees. later. Alya drives him away and confesses to her mother that she is pregnant. About a year after the birth of her son, Ali’s mother asks Dusya, who came on vacation, to place her daughter in the same factory, because the single mother has no future in the village. Alya goes with Dusya to the city, and leaves her son with his mother

The Republic of ShKID (Russian: Respublika ShKID, romanized: Respublika ShKID) is a 1966 Soviet comedy-drama directed by Gennadi Poloka. The premiere of The Republic of ShKID was held on December 29, 1966; in 1967, the film became a box-office leader – it was seen by 32.6 million viewers (12th place). The action takes place in Petrograd in the early 1920s. Throughout the country, as reported in the credits, four million children are homeless. Juvenile offenders are caught by the Cheka and sent to boarding schools and gated colonies. Children who are not chosen by school leaders and colonies are sent to prison. Vikniksor, director of the school-commune named for Dostoevsky (Dostoevsky School-Commune, ShKID), prepares the teaching staff and personnel to welcome the first set of students. They set the table for breakfast, but no one comes to the dining room: the children have stolen keys from the janitor, Meftahutdyn, and left the school. The children throw the keys into a tree so that it is difficult to lock the gates, and the tree is eventually cut down in order to get the keys. Having reveled enough, the children return to school on the evening of the same day and bully the staff. Most of their ire is focused on Elanlyum, the German-language teacher

Three Fat Men (Russian: Three fat men, romanized: Tri fattyaka) is a 1966 Soviet children's fantasy film directed by Aleksey Batalov and Iosif Shapiro based on the eponymous novel by Yury Olesha. The story is set in an unnamed, fantastical city ruled by the Three Fat Men, who mercilessly exploit the people. A traveling caravan of performers, including the clown Augustus, the acrobat Tibul, and the young girl Suok, arrives in the city just as a miners' uprising erupts. Tibul joins the rebels, but their revolt is crushed by the forces of General Karaska. During the bombardment from the palace, a mishap damages the mechanical doll of the heir, Tutti—a lifelike toy resembling a young girl. Meanwhile, the rebel leader Prospero is captured and brought to the palace as part of a victory celebration. While evading soldiers, Tibul seeks refuge in the of the renowned scientist Dr. Gaspard Arneri, who helps him disguise himself. That same night, Dr. Arneri is summoned to the palace to repair the damaged doll and is sent with it under heavy guard. However, the rebels ambush the carriage, mistaking the doctor for a high-ranking official, and the horses bolt with the carriage and the doll. Searching for the lost doll, Dr. Arneri stumbles upon Augustus’s caravan and reunites with Tibul. It is discovered that Suok bears an uncanny resemblance to the doll, and Tibul devises a plan: Suok will impersonate the doll to infiltrate the palace. Suok, posing as the repaired doll, is delivered to Tutti’s chambers, where the lonely boy discovers her secret but chooses not to expose her. Suok retrieves the key to the royal prison and frees Prospero, but her deception is revealed when the real doll is found elsewhere. Suok and Dr. Arneri are arrested and sentenced to execution

1925 Russian engineer Pyotr Garin, using the discovery of Professor Mantsev, creates a weapon of unprecedented destructive power - a hyperboloid, a generator of a powerful heat ray. Many initial of the film reflected critics' dissatisfaction. In particular, the critic V. S. Revich, who specialized in science fiction, brought a class-political reproach to the film in that the social side (“the mechanics of bourgeois relationships, the stock market game, capitalist economy and morality”) of A. Tolstoy’s novel “completely dropped out of the film, what remained was, again, a simplified detective story, a hastily explained scientific one.” A decade and a half later, he assessed the film somewhat differently: “Despite the , which is rare in terms of sonority of names, the film was not a success. A typical mistake was made by film adaptations of large works of prose. The desire not to miss the main plot points leads to fluency - a character flashed by, an event flew by - and further, further, faster; There’s not enough screen time to look at the faces, to understand the essence of the events... The result is an action-adventure action film with a very superficial philosophy

Uncle Tom's Cabin (German: Onkel Toms Hütte) is a 1965 German film directed by Géza von Radványi. The film was entered into the 4th Moscow International Film Festival. It is based on the novel Uncle Tom's Cabin. In the early spring of 1977, the film was reissued in the United States in an edited form, with new scenes directed by Al Adamson. On the heels of the success that year of the mini Roots, the ad campaign for the reissue touted that the film had "ALL the SENSUAL and VIOLENT passions 'ROOTS' couldn't show on TV" and offered "the REAL story of the SLAVES, MASTERS & LOVERS." In France, it was the 63rd top-grossing film of 1965, selling 928,110 tickets at the box office. In Poland, it sold more than 2 million tickets, making it one of the thirteen highest-grossing foreign in Poland as of 1968. In North America, where it was initially released in 1969, the film went on to sell 7,042,254 tickets and gross $10 million. This adds up to more than 9,970,364 tickets sold worldwide

Nocturne" (Latvian: Noktirne) is a 1966 Soviet feature film, war drama. Based on the story of the same name by Jean Griva, a former fighter of the International Brigade. The last stage of the Spanish Civil War. The Republican army retreated beyond the Pyrenees. By chance, the paths of the Latvian Georges, a fighter in one of the detachments, and the French woman, nurse Yvette, cross. They fell in love, but got lost in the chaos of war. Yvette managed to cross the border and hide in her homeland, and Georges ended up in a concentration camp. Several years passed, France was occupied by Nazi troops. In a small Marseilles restaurant, Georges, who escaped from the camp, meets his beloved. Both join the partisans at one of the secret mountain bases. “The City of Masters” is a 1965 Soviet fairy tale film based on the play “The City of Masters, or The Tale of the Two Hunchbacks” by Tamara Gabbe at the Belarusfilm film studio. Katrin Lot works as a sports teacher in Berlin, has two children and is married to a lieutenant captain in the GDR People's Navy. Richard Lot comes every few weeks, is the loving father and is adored by his sons. But Katrin is not happy with the situation because there is no love between the two. While Richard is on vacation again and both of them are spending the day at the zoo with the children, Katrin wants to talk to her husband in the evening and asks him directly why he doesn't want to get a divorce. But for Richard this is not an issue because a lack of affection and habit in marriage is not a reason for divorce for him. He is reminded by his wife that they had not married out of love, but because they had a child that neither of them wanted. In response to Katrin's objection that a marriage that consists of hypocrisy is not a good marriage, he asks what he should say to his comrades in the People's Navy and his political officer Max Braun in the event of a divorce. It goes on like this until he suddenly says that he's going to his office straight away, puts some more money in the cupboard and disappears. The day he returned and explained to his wife that he had called in sick in his unit. But she doesn't want to go to normal daily routine. She tells him that she is aware of his relationships with other women, presents a letter that she found among his things as evidence and asks him to release her and apply for a divorce, but Richard continues to defend himself, pointing out the two children. Katrin Lot tries to arrange a consultation with the divorce judge Teichmann and is told that a lack of love is not a reason for divorce. When she then says that her husband is an officer in the People's Navy, he only gives her urgent advice to stay away from suing. When she gets, her husband comes on a short vacation and has brought his friend, the political officer Max, with him. After Richard explains to her that he has told his party group about the divorce problem, the two men try to dissuade Catherine from thinking about a separation, as their ideas about love sound a lot like garden arbor romance and demand that she show a little more sense of duty for the sake of the children
