“We, the Russian People” is a 1965 Soviet two-part film directed by Vera Stroeva based on the film-novel of the same name by Vsevolod Vishnevsky about the events that took place in a separate regiment of the Russian Imperial Army in 1917. Sergei Eisenstein wanted to direct a film epic based on the novel published in 1937, Efim Dzigan began developing the script, but work was stopped by the management of Mosfilm in 1938. Having recreated in the novel-film “We, the Russian People” the history of the Petrovsky regiment from the end of 1916 to the beginning of 1918, Vishnevsky seemed to show the history of the Russian people, who went through a difficult path from the imperialist war to the civil war, from lawlessness and oppression to revolution and freedom

Summary Contents Subject index In a unique comparative ethnography of two family therapy programs, Gubrium deftly shows how differing organizational perceptions make visible the social construction of domestic disorder. The travelers come across a farm, where they stay overnight with an old woman. She turns out to be a witch and, riding Khoma, flies through the air on him. Khoma manages to break free and beat the witch half to death, while the old woman turns into a girl. Frightened of punishment, Khoma runs to the bursa. There the rector informs him that a lady is dying - the daughter of a famous centurion, the owner of a farm 50 versts from Kyiv, and she wants Khoma to read the funeral service over. her. Khoma is forced to drive, along the way trying to escape from the centurion’s men accompanying him. When Khoma arrives at the farm, the lady dies. The centurion asks Khoma how he met his daughter, but receives no answer. Seeing a dead woman in the upper room, Khoma is convinced that this is the same witch. which he promises a generous reward. A promising graduate of MGIMO, young journalist Yuri Alyabyev (Yuri Vasiliev) has been working with letters from readers for 4 long years at a central paper. Just when the editor-in-chief is finally ready to transfer him to the international department, the head of the letters department sends him on a business trip to the small industrial town of Gornouralsk in order to sort out the written complaints of a certain Anikina (Nadezhda Fedosova). On the advice of the editor of the local paper Reutov (Sergei Nikonenko), he stops at Anikina’s house, to which in a small house s a girl, Shura Okayomova (Galina Polskikh), who works at a local factory. Alyabyev, attracted by Shura’s beauty and intelligence, tries to achieve intimacy with her, but Shura does not dare to do this, although she later regrets for a long time that she did not explain her decision. Alyabyev becomes convinced that Anikina is a malicious slanderer and returns to Moscow. Despite the fact that the editor-in-chief is not satisfied with the result of Alyabiev’s business trip to Gornouralsk, he directs him to get accustomed to the international department and prepare for a trip to Europe. In the company of experienced colleagues, Yuri goes to Geneva, from where he travels to Paris, where he meets Annie Girardot, attends a rehearsal of Mireille Mathieu, and holds discussions with his new friend, American journalist Sid Barton (Anatoly Kryzhansky), proving the advantages of the Soviet way of life. Returning from a business trip, Alyabyev again goes to the Urals. He was never able to forget Shura and wants to meet her again. From Reutov he learns that after his departure, the management of the city and the plant began to receive letters from Anikina about the love affair between him and Okayomova. At the meeting, Shura does not refute the slander and admits his relationship with Alyabyev. By decision of the Komsomol meeting, Shura was moved to the plant’s dormitory. Alyabyev meets Shura, a dramatic showdown occurs, Alyabyev confesses his love to Shura and wants to marry her. The actions taking place in Gornouralsk were filmed on location in the city of Miass, where director Gerasimov’s parents worked and near which he was born. The film views of various parts of the city, including the current Central part of the city at the construction stage, the historical part - Stargorod, Lake Turgoyak

The main character of the film is Silvio (Mikhail Kozakov), a retired hussar. His house is open to the officers of the regiment stationed in the town. Silvio is known as an excellent shooter and carries a story of revenge in his soul: many years ago, he, then still an officer, quarreled with a certain count (Yuri Yakovlev) - a lucky man and the darling of fate, it came to a duel. The count missed the enemy with his first shot and behaved with insulting indifference (he ate cherries while waiting for a return shot), but Silvio, capable of putting a bullet in a bullet, decided not to rush into an answer - he rode off, postponing his shot for many years, deciding to see how the count would behave if the duel took place under completely different circumstances

“Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow” (Italian: Ieri, oggi, domani) is an Italian film directed by Vittorio De Sica, released in 1963. In 1965 he was awarded the Oscar for Best Foreign Film.

Haiduks, haiduts (Hungarian hajdúk - literally “driver”) - armed peasants who fought against Ottoman rule in the Balkans. During the Russian-Turkish War of 1877-1878, many Haiduks fought together with Russian troops for the liberation of Bulgaria.

“I Knew Her Well” (Italian: Io la conoscevo bene) is a 1965 Italian film directed by Antonio Pietrangeli. The film was included in the list of 100 Italian films to preserve, from the post-war to the eighties.

Heaven on One's Head (French: Le Ciel sur la tête, released in the United States as Skies Above) is a 1965 French science fiction film directed by Yves Ciampi. It was entered into the 4th Moscow International Film Festival where it won a Golden Prize.

The Clay Pigeon is a Yugoslav war film from 1966. It was directed by Svetomir Toma Janić, and the screenplay was written by Svetomir Toma Janić and Đorđe Lebović. Sarajevo is under occupation. Two workers from the furnace, Predrag and Beli, fall into the hands of the Gestapo during a raid. The head of the Gestapo, dr. Stahl, by torturing Belog, succeeds in obtaining information about some members of an illegal organization that provides saboteurs with precise information about the movements of the composition with German troops and war materials. The Gestapo has a stgy to turn folk heroes into traitors and sentence them to lynching

The Snow Queen (Russian: Снежная королева, romanized: Snezhnaya koroleva) is a Soviet 1967 fantasy drama film, directed by Gennadi Kazansky and based on the eponymous 1844 fairy tale by Hans Christian Andersen. On a frosty winter evening, the Snow Queen kidnaps Kai and turns his heart into a piece of ice. Gerda, wishing to return Kai goes to for him. She experiences many trials to get to the Snow Queen's palace and to retrieve Kai from icy captivity. The film begins with a storyteller introducing the tale of the Snow Queen. The story follows two children, Gerda and her adopted brother Kay, who with their grandmother. A sinister Counselor, an agent of the Snow Queen, visits their to demand the rare blooming roses gifted by the storyteller, intending to sell them for profit. When refused, the Counselor vows revenge. Soon after, the Snow Queen herself appears, claiming Kay as her own. Though the family resists, she kisses Kay, freezing his heart and changing his personality, making him cruel and distant. Later, during a sledding outing, Kay is lured away by the Snow Queen and taken to her icy palace

A love story between battalion commander Pavel Akimov and military translator Anya Belozerova. Akimov has proven himself to be a good commander, and a translator, Lieutenant Belozerova, is assigned to his battalion.

Tenderness" is a feature film shot in 1966 at the Uzbekfilm studio by director Elyor Ishmukhamedov. The film was released on August 1, 1967. The plot of the 24-year-old director's thesis is built around the theme of growing up, youth, first love and first problems. The film takes place in Tashkent. Compositionally, the film consists of three short stories about young people connected by family, friendship and love relationships. The first short story, “Sanjar,” is named after the main character. Sitting Pretty is a 1948 American comedy film directed by Walter Lang from a screenplay by F. Hugh Herbert, adapted from the novel Belvedere by Gwen Davenport. The film stars Robert Young, Maureen O'Hara, and Clifton Webb, about a family who hires the mysterious Lynn Belvedere to babysit their rowdy children. Upon its release by 20th Century Fox in April 1948, Sitting Pretty became a box-office success. Webb received critical praise for his performance of Belvedere, which spawned two sequels. In the suburban Hummingbird Hill, lawyer Harry King and his wife Tacey have trouble retaining a nanny for their three young, rambunctious boys: Larry and Tony, both of whom get into frequent mischief with the family dog ​​Henry; and baby Roddy. When the latest in a string of servants (all women) quits, Tacey advertises for a replacement and hires Lynn Belvedere sight unseen. However, she discovers that Lynn Belvedere is actually a man upon his arrival, a mysterious one with many skills and achievements – and who declares himself to detest children. Nevertheless, the Kings reluctantly agree to a trial period during which Belvedere quickly wins over the boys. Hamida is a feature film from 1966 that was co-produced between the GDR and Tunisia and directed by Jean Michaud-Mailland. The film is based on the story Pas de Cheval pour Hamida by Gabrielle Estivals. Tunisia during the period of the French protection. In a documentary-like episode at the beginning of the film, Tunisians violently rebel against the French. A Tunisian commander recognizes a familiar face in a killed Frenchman: Renaud. A few years earlier, Renaud grew up in Tunisia as the grandson of a large French landowner. Renaud's father, his grandfather's son, died as a soldier. The mother feels lonely in rural Tunisia. She would also prefer to have her son in France. Despite their different social status, Renaud is friends with Hamida, a Tunisian shepherd boy of the same age. Together they explore the surrounding landscapes and play with each other. A sheep from Hamida's herd is lost. While ing for the animal, Hamida falls into a river. Renaud saves his friend's life. To protect Hamida from punishment from his strict grandfather, Renaud steals a sheep from the neighbor's herd, but the fraud is exposed

The Magician" is a Soviet black and white feature film directed by Pyotr Todorovsky, filmed in 1967 at the Experimental Creative Film Studio (Moscow). The first film from this studio. The main character of the film, Viktor Mikhailovich Kukushkin, is an elderly magician and puppeteer, a shy and kind man, but at the same time passionate and with a sense of self-esteem. Due to the lack of official speaking engagements, he is forced to work part-time at apartment buildings, where he meets physics students. Gradually, Kukushkin enters their “commune”, teaches them some tricks, but notes with regret that he is an absolutely secondary person for them - everyone has their own life, their own activities and interests, their own idea of art. One day he meets a young beauty Elena, already familiar to him from some apartment buildings, and falls in love with her. Together they arrange “something like a wedding,” but the views of the magician and his newly-made wife are diametrically opposed: Elena wants Kukushkin to be both a creative person and a successful worker; Viktor Mikhailovich does not want to bend to his superiors and business relationships. The wedding is upset. Not at all desperate, Kukushkin performs magic tricks on the playground and distributes oranges to children - the audience who needs his performances most

Tanya is a little girl who has withdrawn into herself because of a tragic incident - her father, a military pilot, died in peacetime, during a test flight. The little girl's longing for her father becomes unbearable, she even runs to watch the planes fly by, in the hope that she will finally see her dad there, but he still does not return. One day, Major Lukyanov appears in Tanya’s life, and he very quickly manages to become friends with Tanya. Having found a friend in him, the girl invites him and introduces him to her mother. But anxiety creeps into the child’s soul: after all, Lukyanov is also a pilot, only not “No. 33” as her father was, but “No. 57”... In the film you can see supersonic MiG-21 aircraft. The main consultant of the film is V. A. Kolesnik, flights for filming were carried out by 1st pilot class Major Orest Polyakov. One Million Years B.C. is a 1966 British adventure fantasy film directed by Don Chaffey. The film was produced by Hammer Film Productions and Seven Arts, and is a remake of the 1940 American fantasy film One Million B.C.. The film stars Raquel Welch and John Richardson, set in a fictional age of cavemen and dinosaurs existing together. Location scenes were filmed on the Canary Islands in the middle of winter, in late 1965. The UK release prints of this film were printed in dye transfer Technicolor. The U.S. version released by 20th Century Fox was cut by nine minutes, printed in DeLuxe Color, and released in 1967. Like the original film, this remake is largely ahistorical. It portrays dinosaurs and humans living at the same point in time; according to the geological time scale, the last non-avian dinosaurs became extinct 66 million years ago, and modern humans (Homo sapiens) did not exist until about 300,000 years B.C. Ray Harryhausen, who animated all of the dinosaur attacks using stop-motion animation techniques, commented on the U.S. King Kong DVD that he did not make One Million Years B.C. for "professors...who probably don't go to see these kinds of movies anyway." This is a story of long, long ago, when the world was just beginning... A young world, a world early in the morning of time. A hard, unfriendly world. Creatures who sit and wait. Creatures who must kill to. And man, superior to the creatures only in his cunning. There are not many men yet. Just a few tribes scattered across the wilderness. The Punisher" is a Soviet feature film by Greek director Manos Zacharias, directed by him during his political emigration to the USSR. The film was shot at the Mosfilm studio in 1968 (released on movie screens in 1969). Soldier Vangelis takes part in the execution of a communist, for which he is discharged out of turn. One of Vangelis's colleagues, Dimitris, refused to take part in the execution, for which he was put under arrest, and Vangelis was ordered to take his place. In the city, Vangelis meets with his friend Maria and friends. But it was on this day that Vangelis felt uneasy. He wants to confess to the girl that he unwittingly committed murder, but he doesn’t have the courage. However, he also cannot bear the overwhelming burden of doubt and gives vent to his bitterness in a street fight with a tipsy passerby who pestered Maria, Vangelis finds shelter in a local church, where he confesses to the local priest, who makes Vangelis understand that he still condemns him, because during the Second World War he himself killed many Gestapo men to avenge the death of his parents, but in the end did not find peace of mind, since killing people, in his opinion, is still terrible. Vangelis then comes to Maria’s friends, but even there he does not find peace - first, from a newspaper article, he learns that the executed communist was only 19 years old, and then the friends’ conversation turns into a dispute on the topic that the Junta regime will ultimately lead to a civil war repeating in the near future, in which Vangelis “will shoot at them.” Vangelis ultimately finds Maria at dawn the day. Their meeting is full of tenderness and bitterness, and the confession of the punishing soldier is painful. Vangelis admits to participating in the shooting and decides that it is better for them to separate. He accompanies Maria to her work, after which he is arrested by a patrol for a night fight, but now he is no longer the submissive, unreasoning soldier he was before - when he is taken to the unit, his entourage is asked to help saddle a loose horse, but Vangelis frees the latter. In the final scene, Vangelis sits in the same cell with Dimitris and asks him if the person shot was his relative, which is why Dimitris may have refused to participate. Dimitris replies that he does not, thereby making it clear that he adheres to the same principles as the priest - killing is bad

Gladiator (Latin gladiator - "swordsman", from gladius - "sword", "gladius") - a fighter in Ancient Rome who fought with his own kind or wild animals for the amusement of the public in special arenas for the right to be freed from slavery. The main reason for the emergence of gladiatorial games was a funeral rite borrowed from the Etruscans, similar to ancient wrestling in Japan.

The scientific name of the genus (Latin Helianthus, “sunny flower”), comes from the Greek words helius (“sun”) and anthemon (“flower”). The Russian name arose due to the fact that plants of this genus, to a greater extent than other plants, are characterized by so-called heliotropism - the rotation of open inflorescences facing the sun following its movement across the sky (a special case of phototropism).

Senior bank cashier Mitrofan Ilyich Koretsky decides not to evacuate from the town bordering Latvia. The young typist Musya Volkova remained with him - she did not make it to the transport. Two soldiers brought jewelry to the bank building that had been taken from the car of the blown-up train. Under the very noses of German soldiers, a cashier and a typist carry more than 17 kg of jewelry out of the city. The Nazis learn about the valuable cargo and begin searching for the fugitives. On the road, Mitrofan Ilyich dies, and Musya continues on her way alone. Meets local residents and ends up in a partisan detachment. They wanted to take the jewelry out by plane, but they had to carry the gold on foot. She walked six hundred kilometers behind enemy lines before meeting the soldiers of the Red Army

Two stories about the workers' and peasants' army" is a Soviet two-part feature film filmed in 1970 by director Vasily Ordynsky. 1918 The Commissioner of the All-Russian Collegium for the Formation of the Red Army, Dmitry Amelin, was sent to the 38th Grenadier Regiment, which had left its position without permission, to encourage soldiers to join the Red Army. Amelin, not without difficulty, manages to overcome the hostility and misunderstanding of the soldiers, find a common language with the anarchist agitator sailor Volodya Koltsov, and with the help of a military officer, second lieutenant Nikolai Kutasov, turn the regiment into a combat-ready unit capable of withstanding the onslaught of German troops. On February 23, 1918, in the vicinity of Petrograd, the regiment took on superior enemy forces and emerged victorious. teaches the commissar the basics of military art in practice. Friendly relations begin between Amelin, Kutasov and Kutasov’s wife Natasha. After the battle, the entire regiment joins the Red Army - except for Kutasov. He is not an opponent of Soviet power, but he foresees a civil fratricidal war and does not want to participate in it Some time later, Kutasov finds himself in Moscow on Red Square, where, in the presence of Lenin, the newly. formed units of the Red Army take the oath. Impressed by what he saw, Kutasov changes his decision

Director (from Latin dirigere, directum - from di and regere - “to manage”, plural - director; obsolete female - director) - manager, manager, official, chief, leader, unit, department, institution, company, enterprise or educational institution. Director, in Russia, until 1917, is the name of officials at the head of departments and offices of ministries and various educational and scientific institutions: gymnasiums, lyceums, institutes, public schools (the whole province), libraries, museums, conservatories, observatories, as well as members of the boards of railway and other joint-stock companies.

Sevastopol" is a Soviet film, a historical drama based on the events between two revolutions in Russia in the Black Sea Fleet, filmed in 1970 at the Odessa Film Studio by director Valery Isakov based on the story of the same name by Alexander Malyshkin. The main events take place in 1917 in Sevastopol. Sergei Shelekhov, a former university student who has just completed an acceled military course and was promoted to officer, arrives on a fictional ship, the minelayer of the Black Sea Fleet "Kacha". Despite the democratic ferment at the beginning of the year, “defencists” predominate in the fleet, whose line is personalized in the figure of the commander of the Black Sea Fleet, Admiral A.V. After meeting with the Bolshevik Zinchenko, Sergei’s political views gradually move to the left, and now he joins the Bolsheviks. events, when on November 12 (25) a flotilla consisting of the destroyer Captain Saken, two minesweepers, several small ships and a landing party of sailors left Sevastopol for Rostov. The flotilla was commanded by the “commission of five” elected by the First All-Black Sea Congress, headed by the Bolshevik sailor V. E. Drachuk On November 24 (December 7), she, having made calls to the ports of. Berdyansk, Mariupol and Taganrog, arrived in Rostov, where the Black Sea people took part in battles with the Cossacks and volunteers

In the Berendey village, a beautiful but emotionless girl, Snegurochka (the Snow Maiden), appears. Although many young men admire her, including the charming Lel, her heart remains cold, and she no affection in return. Kupava and Mizgir, a betrothed couple, attend a festival with Kupava's friends. However, upon seeing Snegurochka, Mizgir abandons Kupava, publicly declaring that he no longer loves her and has fallen for Snegurochka instead. Accused of inconstancy, Mizgir defends himself, saying, "The heart knows no command. I loved Kupava before, but now I love Snegurochka." At a gathering, the Berendey king decrees that whoever can win Snegurochka's love before dawn, as the Sun God Yarilo rises, will marry her. As the villagers form couples, Lel pairs with Kupava, giving her a chance to move on from her heartbreak

Corazón salvaje (English: Wild Heart) is a Mexican telenovela produced and broadcast by Telesistema Mexicano (now Televisa) in 1966. It is the second of five screen adaptations of the novel of the same name by Caridad Bravo Adams. This telenovela starred singer Julissa while the 1977 production starred singer Angélica María who had ly had the role of Monica in the 1968 film version. Actor Ernesto Alonso produced both telenovela versions. The role of Juan del Diablo went to Enrique Lizalde who, with Julissa, had ly starred in another Bravo Adams’ story, La mentira. This was the first starring role of Enrique Álvarez Félix, son of actress María Félix, in the role of the antagonist Renato Duchamp, the legitimate half-brother of Juan del Diablo. It was also the second time Jacqueline Andere (in the role of Aimée, Monica's sister) co-starred with Enrique Lizalde, both being stage actors

Guardianship is one of the types of family placement for minors (under 14 years of age) left without parental care, as well as a form of protection of the rights and interests of a citizen declared incompetent by a court due to a mental disorder. Guardianship is a type of family arrangement for a minor who has reached the age of 14 and is left without parental care, or a form of protection of the civil rights and interests of an adult who has been recognized by a court as having limited legal capacity (for example, due to alcohol or drug abuse or due to a mental disorder), can also be established in relation to persons who, due to physical disabilities (blindness, deafness), cannot independently exercise legal capacity.

According to data received by the NKVD, a German sabotage group plans to blow up a plant in Moscow where the production of rocket-propelled mortars (Katyusha) is to begin. In order to find out the plans of enemy agents, including intelligence officers working under diplomatic cover in the German embassy, ​​and prevent them from coming true, the NKVD sends to the plant under the name of Nikolai Petrov, on whom German intelligence is counting, a very similar Sergei Biryukov, a reserve commander far from the special services, a man “like everyone else” (hence the title of the film: “One of Us”).

The film begins with an episode of examination of a patient by radiologist Evgeniy. Based on the results of the doctor's examination and x-ray, he observes that she has health problems, possibly psychologically related to the separation from her loved one. Evgeniy considers this problem not worthy of attention. In a shoe workshop, he accidentally meets a young student at a pedagogical school. Evgeniy continues the dating process with great interest. Masha immediately realized that this was true love. But for Evgeny, living together turned out to be unusual and uncomfortable. Masha, seeing his confusion, leaves. Evgeniy is trying to renew his relationship with a former acquaintance, but nothing works out for him. Evgeniy begins to understand that he truly loves Masha and what the final break is. An exciting love story between an intellectual and an illiterate girl-witch unfolds in the film “Olesya,” based on the most famous story of the same name by Alexander Kuprin. Wandering through the forest, Ivan Timofeevich finds a dilapidated hut on the edge of the swamp.

Nina" is a 1971 Soviet film directed by Alexei Shvachko, a war drama based on the true story of underground fighter Nina Sosnina, who was posthumously awarded the title of Hero of the Soviet Union. The film was watched by 21,600,000 viewers - 30th place in the 1971 box office. In the town of Malin, Zhitomir region, punitive forces are shooting underground fighters. But yesterday’s schoolchildren are replacing those executed - Komsomol member Nina Sosnina and her friends create their own underground group, post leaflets, conduct propaganda and subversive work. Nina establishes contact with the partisans, joins Pavel Taraskin’s group, helps her father, surgeon Sosnin, ope and treat wounded partisans and underground fighters Soon the group is already conducting real combat operations, and now the fascists are conducting a real hunt for them, thinking that a detachment of saboteurs. is ope against them. The traitor points the Germans to the Sosnins’ house, father and daughter die without wanting to surrender

Mayerling is a 1968 romantic tragedy film starring Omar Sharif, Catherine Deneuve, James Mason, Ava Gardner, Geneviève Page, James Robertson Justice and Andréa Parisy. It was written and directed by Terence Young. The film was made by Les Corona and Winchester and distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was based on the novels Mayerling by French tennis player and writer Claude Anet and L'Archiduc by Michel Arnold and the 1936 film Mayerling, directed by Anatole Litvak, which dealt with the real-life Mayerling incident. In 1880s Vienna, Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria clashes with his father, Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria and his mother Empress Elisabeth, about the implementation of progressive policies for the empire. Rudolf soon feels he is a man born at the wrong time in a country that does not agree on the need for social reform. The Prince of Wales, later to become King Edward VII of Britain, visits Vienna and provides comic relief. Later in Hungary a popular revolt breaks out, which Rudolf begs his father, Francis Joseph, to tole, but to no avail

“Only the Dead Will Answer” (Polish: Tylko umarły odpowie) is a Polish detective feature film filmed in 1969 by director Sylvester Chęciński at the Iluzjon studio. Police captain Wujcik is investigating the murder of a cashier at a state-owned enterprise.

King Lear" is a Soviet black and white two-part widescreen feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1970 based on the tragedy of the same name by William Shakespeare. The last film directed by Grigory Kozintsev. King Lear, in his declining years, decides to retire and divide his kingdom between his three daughters. To determine the size of their parts, he asks each of them to say how much she loves him. The eldest daughters - Goneril and Regan - flatter the king in order to get a larger of the kingdom, while Cordelia, Lear's youngest daughter, refuses to flatter, saying that her love is higher than this. The angry father disowns his youngest daughter and drives out the Earl of Kent, who tried to intercede for Cordelia. Lear divides the kingdom between the eldest and middle daughters, leaving himself a retinue of 100 people and the title of King, telling the eldest daughters that he will visit them every month. He gives his youngest daughter as a wife to the French King, without any dowry. The illegitimate son of the Earl of Gloucester, Edmond, who does not want to put up with his position, slanderers the legitimate son of Gloucester, Edgar, who then runs away from and joins the wandering homeless

name_original: How I Unleashed World War II
web_summary: How I Unleashed World War II is a 1970 Polish comedy film directed by Tadeusz Chmielewski and based on Kazimierz Sławiński's novel "Przygody kanonier Dolasa" (The Adventures of Dolas the Cannoneer). It was shot in Sochi, Baku, Poświatne and Łódź, among other places.

“Black Angels” (Bulgarian: Chernite angeli) is a film based on the book “In the Name of the People” by Mitka Grybcheva. The film was awarded the “Main Prize” at the XVII International Film Festival in Karlovy Vary in 1970.

name_original: Goya or the Hard Way to Enlightenment
web_summary: Goya or the Hard Way to Enlightenment (German: Goya – oder der arge Weg der Erkenntnis) is a 1971 East German drama film directed by Konrad Wolf. It was entered into the 7th Moscow International Film Festival where it won a Special Prize. It is based on a novel with the same title by Lion Feuchtwanger. The painter Francisco de Goya has achieved reputation and prosperity through his talent and creative prowess. His clients come from the most important houses in Madrid and so he gradually comes to the royal court of Charles IV. He is passionately drawn to the Duchess Alba and at the same time hates the decadent aristocrat in her. He believes in the king and the church, enjoying his position at court. His colleague and friend Esteve him the contradictions of this closed world and leads him to the simple people of the country. In a Madrid tavern he meets the singer Maria Rosario; later he has to see her being condemned by the Inquisition. He is deeply shocked by the song that Maria has to recite as proof of her guilt. The further he penetrates into the life of the people, drawing motifs for his art from it, the greater his inner pain becomes in view of the conditions in the country. His relationship with Alba leads to self-destructive behavior and so he suffers a sudden hearing loss. He turns his on the farm and travels completely deaf to his mother's in Aragon. With the help of his companion Esteve, he finds his way to his work, which leads him to an inner turning away from the values ​​of society and the church. He is plagued by demons whom he recognizes in their deeds and their social influence and which flows into his work. He himself falls into the clutches of the Inquisition; the Grand Inquisitor implores him to refuse this idea. But Goya is firmly established in the belief that the misery and horror arises from the circumstances themselves and remains convinced of the truth of his pictures. Khatabala” (Armenian: Խաթաբալա “trouble, failure, misfortune”) is a film directed by Yuri Erzinkyan, shot at the Armenfilm film studio in 1971. Screen adaptation of the play of the same name by Gabriel Sundukyan. The film begins with pictures of life in old Tiflis, its noisy streets, Maidans, shops and dukhans. A young man who returned after studying in St. Petersburg, Gevork Masisyan finds himself in this motley world and unexpectedly notices the beautiful Natalya entering the house of the merchant Zambakhov. Enchanted by her beauty, he wants to marry her. Seeing the merchant Isaiah, he asks for help in matchmaking. But the beautiful stranger turned out to be Isaiah’s wife. This is how a misunderstanding, confusion, commotion, or, in Armenian, “khatabala” arises. The cunning Isai decides to take advantage of the situation to help his senior partner Zambakhov marry his ugly daughter Margarit to the naive Masisyan. The fact is that, according to custom, the groom could not see his bride until the very day of the engagement. And the scammers hoped that at the last moment he would not raise a scandal and deprive himself of his dowry

Dauria” is a Soviet two-part feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1971 by director Viktor Tregubovich based on the novel of the same name by Konstantin Sedykh about the fate of the Transbaikal Cossacks at the turning point of the First World War, the Revolution of 1917 and the Civil War in Russia. Summer 1914. A detachment of Cossacks encounters a convoy carrying convicts. The Cossacks recognize their comrade Vasyukha Ulybin in one of the convicts, and they are overwhelmed with mixed feelings. A convict is a disgrace for the village, and especially for his family. The Cossack village lives its daily life. The Cossacks go for walks, organize wolf hunts, conflict over hayfields with local peasants, and engage in drill training and horse riding. A suspicious blacksmith, Nagorny, appears in the village, who does not go to church, but knows his business well. He conveys the about the convict Vasily to the main character, the young Cossack Roman Ulybin. Meanwhile, the blacksmith Platon Volokitin notices the light in the forge at night and discovers a secret meeting of underground workers there. The Cossacks, led by the village ataman Elisey Kargin, arrest the blacksmith and conduct a . They manage to discover a cache of weapons

The Hanging Gardens of Babylon are one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, which was an engineering structure in Babylon with a cascade of multi-level gardens, where numerous species of trees, shrubs and vines grew, giving the impression of a large green mountain. The only one of the Seven Wonders, the location of which has not been definitively established and, moreover, the very fact of its existence is questioned➤, since no Babylonian texts in which these gardens are mentioned have survived, descriptions of the gardens are available only in late ancient Greek and Roman authors➤, and archaeological excavations in the area of ​​​​the supposed location of the gardens also did not produce results.

Kyz-Zhibek (Kazakh: Қыз Жі held, Qyz Jıbek, lit. 'the Beauty Jibek') is a Kazakh poetic folk legend of the 16th century, which tells about a love story happening in tumultuos times. The love story of Tölegen, the brave warrior, and the beauty Jibek ends tragically because of inter-family strife. Tölegen is foully murdered by Bekejan (the batyr of the rival family), who earlier strived for the hand of Jibek. Jibek commits suicide after learning about the death of Tölegen. The romantic epic, unfolding at the beginning of the 16th century, when the Kazakh Khanate was first formed from many steppe clans and tribes, was recorded in the 19th century. It was first published in Kazan in 1894 in a version prepared by a Kazakh ethnographer and poet Jüsipbek Shayhislamuly. Today, sixteen original epic versions are known

Effi Briest is a television film by Wolfgang Luderer from 1970 based on the novel of the same name by Theodor Fontane. It was produced by DEFA for German television. 17-year-old Effi Briest, who is having fun in the garden with her friends, is brought into the house by her mother because Baron Geert von Innstetten has arrived. While still in the hallway, the mother reveals to her daughter that the Baron has just asked for Effi's hand in marriage. When a friend asked if he was the right one, Effi replied that everyone is the right one if they are of nobility, have a position and look good. The wedding is celebd quickly, and Effi then moves to Kessin in Western Pomerania to with Geert, who works there as a district administrator. But immediately after she arrives and is introduced to the staff, she gets a shock when she enters the house. A stuffed crocodile and a shark hang from the ceiling of the entrance hall. Other exotic figures are standing around that come from the owner of the house, the so-called Chinese sailor Captain Thomsen, who d here with his Chinese servant after selling his ship. Over a first cup of tea in the new , Geert explains to her that there isn't much going on socially in Kessin, because among the almost 3,000 residents there are only the preacher, a magist, the rector and the pilot commander. In the end, only the pharmacist Gießhübler and a handful of nobles remain in the area with whom you can meet. The morning Effi sleeps a little longer while Geert is already working at the district office. But the housekeeper Johanna tells her that her husband wants to come for his first breakfast in the new. She also explains to Effi what noises worried her during the night. They came from a hall above their room, where the curtains drag across the floor when the windows are open. Of course, Effi has to take a look into the room used as a storage room and is shocked to see a picture of a Chinese man there. During breakfast together, Geert promises her that he will have the curtains that are causing the noise shortened. At 11 a.m. sharp, the pharmacist Gießhübler arrives to make his inaugural visit to the young baroness. She takes the opportunity to ask whether you can go dancing in Kessin and is answered by Gießhübler that there is an annual New Year's Eve ball and the usual carnival celebrations. After saying goodbye to the pharmacist, Effi sits down on a bench in the entrance hall, is frightened again by the scary figures, s her eyes and dreams of playing with her friends in her parents' house. Only Geert's return brings her to the present. He surprises her with an inaugural visit to the Grasenabbs in the afternoon, but also warns that she shouldn't expect too much, because such compulsory visits also have their tiring sides. Effi is bored during this and the following visits to the other nobles in the coming weeks, as it is always the same conversations and the men often retreat to a gentlemen's group

Tronka" is a 1971 Soviet black-and-white widescreen feature film, shot by director Arthur Voitetsky at the Alexander Dovzhenko Film Studio based on the novel of the same name by Oles Gonchar (short stories “Polygon” and “Iron Island”). The action takes place on a steppe military training ground, where shepherds have long grazed sheep. One of them, the old shepherd Gorpishchenko (V. Alekseev), who embodies folk wisdom, has long conversations with the pilot Uralov (A. Dzhigarkhanyan). Actually, these are not even conversations, but an exchange of remarks between people who understand each other well. The pilot's family experiences grief - his little daughter dies. The pain of Uralov and his wife is conveyed with restraint, subtly, without melodramatic effects.I. symbolism and a slow pace of action

Pan Tau (Czech for "Mr. Tau") is a character created for a children's television . There were 33 episodes in 3 made by the Czechoslovak Television (ČST) in cooperation with Barrandov Studios and the West German TV network Westdeutscher Rundfunk (WDR). A pilot film was shot in 1966, and 33 episodes were made from 1970 until 1979. The project ended with a feature film in 1988. The protagonist Pan Tau, who generally didn't speak and communicated through pantomime, was played by Otto Šimánek (1925–1992). The was written by Ota Hofman and directed by Jindřich Polák. The plot of each episode was generally comical but contained some kind of problem for a child, and here Pan Tau found the way to solve the problem. Pan Tau always had a gentle expression and a friendly smile, he was elegantly dressed in a stroller, with an umbrella and a white carnation in the lapel. Foremost, he was famous for his magic bowler hat. By tapping on his hat, Pan Tau was able to change his appearance into a puppet, to conjure up miscellaneous objects or to do other magic. His most characteristic behaviour is that he would help children who were experiencing some sort of difficulties in-between their dreams and reality, like finding a place for skiing, settling family problems on Christmas, and even give a boy a good time at a fair when he is supposed to have piano lessons. To adults, he usually remained invisible

“The Musician’s Sister” is a large-format feature film (musical comedy) about the life of high school students in the 70s of the 20th century, filmed by brothers-directors Pavel and Isidor Chomsky at the Mosfilm studio in 1971. The script was written by Anatoly Aleksin based on his story “My Brother Plays the Clarinet” and the play of the same name, based on which theater director Pavel Chomsky previously staged a performance that was a great success with the audience at the Moscow Youth Theater.

“Anvil or Hammer” (Bulgarian: Anvil or chuk, German: Amboss oder Hammer sein) is a political two-part feature film with detective elements, co-produced by Bulgaria, the GDR, and the USSR, filmed in 1972. The film is about the dramatic events of 1933 during the famous Leipzig trial of the Bulgarian communist Georgi Dimitrov, accused with his comrades of burning down the Reichstag, after the Nazis came to power in Germany.

The boxing community solemnly sees off its comrade, five-time champion of the USSR, Europe, and the Olympics, Honored Master of Sports Pyotr Isaev, who decided to end his career. He fought 296 fights, winning 283 of them. Five years later, police major Pyotr Isaev is investigating the case of an attack on a collector. The unarmed criminal stunned the victim with a powerful blow, and at the same time knocked out two soldiers who rushed after him. The collector, who broke his head in a fall, dies in the hospital. After interrogating the soldier, Isaev understands that judging by the technique of the blows, the criminal is an experienced boxer. The for the criminal does not yield results. Isaev decides to take part in the city championship, hoping that his return will become a sensation and will attract the robber to the spectacle. His former coach Ostrovidov takes this with indignation, but still becomes Isaev’s coach-second. Soldiers along with police officers are present in the hall. The years after leaving professional sports are taking their toll, and it is not easy for Isaev to fight younger opponents. Isaev barely wins the first fight on points with candidate Yuri Frolov (SO “Burevestnik”), knocking him down. The fight with master of sports Sergei Silin (SO “Labor Reserves”) Isaev almost loses, having been knocked down. However, he manages to knock out his assertive opponent. Isaev with a broken eyebrow goes out to the rising star, master of sports Vladimir Smirnov (SO "Spartak"). The coach insists that Isaev withdraw from the fight, otherwise he will be taken out of the ring. Nevertheless, Isaev decides to enter the ring. Isaev's comrades - former boxers - demand an explanation from him, he opens up to them, they decide to help the police. The soldiers notice a criminal in the crowd of spectators, colleagues inform Isaev about this. Isaev goes all-in, trying to crush the enemy in a frantic attack. However, Smirnov skillfully defends himself, goes on the attack and knocks out Isaev. After the competition, the police and Isaev’s comrades detain the criminal

The film begins with a chess game, which is broadcast to the audience, among whom is little Seryozha Khlebnikov with his father. Carried away by the analysis of the game, on his way , the father gets hit by a car and dies. Even at the funeral, the boy, without being distracted, solves a chess study. Later, Sergei, left with his mother, completely focuses on the game. As a child, Sergei was friends with a girl Lena. Having become a young man, he meets her again. Romantic feelings arise between Lena and “Khlebushko”, but Elena’s move separates them. During a simultaneous game session, many years later, he notices among the players Lena, now a translator Elena Andreevna Dontsova. They resume their relationship and get married, but family life does not work out, since Sergei is forced to devote all his attention to chess, and not to the woman he loves. They break up. Four years pass. Sergei's coach Victor convinces him to act more pragmatically, not to get carried away by the beauty of the game, but to play for the result. Khlebnikov fulfills the grandmaster standard and performs successfully in tournaments. An old friend Gena Orlov follows his performances and finds Sergei during international competitions. Gena invites Sergei to contact Lena. Returning from abroad, Sergei comes to Lena, but they do not find a common language and break up

Mackenna's Gold is a 1969 American feature film starring Gregory Peck, Omar Sharif, Telly Savalas, Ted Cassidy, Julie Newmar and Camilla Sparve, based on the novel of the same name by writer Will Henry. The novel is based on the legend of Adams' Lost Gold.

“Kalina Krasnaya” is a 1973 Soviet full-length color dramatic feature film by director and screenwriter Vasily Shukshin, based on his story of the same name at the Mosfilm film studio. Shukshin's last directorial work (he died six months after the film's release).

name_original: Unbelievable Adventures of Italians in Russia
web_summary: “The Incredible Adventures of Italians in Russia” (Italian: Una matta, matta, matta corsa in Russia - “One crazy, crazy, crazy race across Russia”) is a joint Soviet-Italian adventure comedy film, filmed in 1973 by director Eldar Ryazanov at the Mosfilm film studio. A ninety-two-year-old woman, who turns out to be a Russian emigrant, is taken to one of the Roman hospitals.

“Only “old men” go into battle” is a 1973 Soviet black-and-white feature film directed by Leonid Bykov, which tells about the everyday life of fighter pilots during the Great Patriotic War. Released in 1974, the film attracted 44.

The film shows the events on the Don during the Great Patriotic War and after it, taking place over almost twenty years. At the center of the film is the love story of a courageous and strong woman, integral in her directness, Antonina Kashirina, to the officer Nikitin, whom she saved during the war.

Co-written by star Gojko Mitic and director Gottfried Kolditz, Apachen is the eighth installation in the very loose Indianerfilm - like the other it emphasizes the plight of the Native Americans (this time the Apache tribes of the Southwest) against the cruelty of the Americans and is loosely based on the 1837 Santa Rita massacre (although with the events transposed to the mid-1840s). The was conceived as anti-American propaganda but this story in particular has some very strong shades of gray - the Apaches are seen taking out their revenge not only on the Americans behind the massacre but also on the Mexican townspeople, including those who actually stood up against it

Treasure of Silver Lake (German: Der Schatz im Silbersee) is a 1962 Western film directed by Harald Reinl, loosely based on German author Karl May's 1891 novel of the same name. It was the first in a highly-successful series of films based on May's works by the West German studios Rialto and Constantin Film, starring American actor Lex Barker as the frontiersman Old Shatterhand and French actor Pierre Brice as the Apache warrior Winnetou.
Sergey and Tatyana love each other very much. Sergei is conscripted into the army (marine corps), and Tatyana is waiting for his return.

“Remember Your Name” (Polish: Zapamiętaj imię swoje) is a Soviet-Polish full-length military drama feature film directed by Sergei Kolosov, filmed in 1974 jointly by the film studios “Mosfilm” (USSR) and “Illusion” (Poland). In Polish distribution, the film was shown with subtitles; the speech of the Polish actors was not drowned out by the translator's voice.

Elephants Are My Friends (Hindi हाथी मेरे साथी, Haathi Mere Saathi) is a 1971 Indian Hindi language drama film directed by M. Thirumugam from a screenplay by the Salim-Javed duo with dialogues by Inder Raj Anand.

name_russian: О тех, кого помню и люблю
web_summary: “About Those Whom I Remember and Love” is a Soviet full-length wide-format color feature film produced at the Lenfilm Film Studio in 1973 by directors Anatoly Vekhotko and Natalia Troshchenko based on the documentary story “Girl Team” by P. Zavodchikov and S. Samoilov.
“The New Centurions” is a film directed by Richard Fleischer; a film adaptation of the novel of the same name by American writer Joseph Wambaugh. A film about the work of the Los Angeles police.

“The Light at the End of the Tunnel” is a Soviet action-packed feature film filmed in 1974 at the Riga Film Studio. The first of two films in a film dilogy united by the same characters (policemen: Janis Krastins, Laux, Jazep Karlovich; criminals: Evald Apse, Pavel Nasonov).

“Moscow, my love” (Japanese: Moscow my love) is a Soviet-Japanese color feature film filmed at the Mosfilm studio and the Japanese Toho-Eiga association in 1974 by directors Alexander Mitta and Kenji Yoshida. Japanese dancer Yuriko Ono was invited to Moscow to study the art of ballet.
“The Incorrigible Liar” is a 1973 Soviet film comedy directed by Villen Azarov. Another title is “The Incorrigible Liar.

“With Clean Hands” (Romanian Cu mâinile curate, internationally known as “With Clean Hands”) is a detective film directed by Sergiu Nicolaescu, commissioned by the Romanian Ministry of Internal Affairs. The film premiered on October 30, 1972, and the audience in Romania exceeded 7 million viewers.

name_original: Tall Blond Man with One Black Shoe, The

Toulouse thinks he knows the identity of the spy pulling the strings and hits upon idea: he will convince this man, Bernard Milan (Bernard Blier), that there is an agent arriving at the airport who is privy to top secret information, the twist being, this fellow will be picked at random and have no idea he is the center of such espionage

Slaves is a 1969 American drama film co-written and directed by Herbert Biberman. The film stars Dionne Warwick (in her screen acting debut), Ossie Davis, and Stephen Boyd. Set in the 1850s Southern United States, the film follows Cassy and Luke, two black slaves who are sold to the sadistic plantation owner MacKay. He wants labor from the men and sex from the women. On this, he is determined to exploit both Cassy and Luke. The film opened at the Hippodrome Theater in Baltimore on May 6, 1969. It grossed $28,000 in its opening week. It was also entered into the 1969 Cannes Film Festival

The events of the film, unlike the novel, occur in chronological order. In addition, there are significant plot differences with the original source. In particular, in the film, Andrei’s assistance to the captive Margrave von zur Mühlen-Schönau in the latter’s departure to his homeland is presented not as a forgery of documents, but as a regular request to his friend Kurt for assistance in this matter. And as a result of this, the ending of the picture also differs significantly from the novel: Kurt Van returns to Germany and, having become a participant in the November Revolution, dies, being shot by a detachment under the command of von zur Mühlen-Schönau. The film ends against the backdrop of a theatrical performance in Petrograd with the reading of two letters addressed to the main character: one written by Kurt before the execution, the other left by Rita before her decision to leave Andrei for his life with the arriving Marie Urbach. In the fall of 1919, Andrei Startsov comes from the city of Semidol (the name is made up) to Petrograd. He was mobilized into the army and arrived at his place of duty, but instead of being sent to active units, Andrei was left as a clerk at headquarters. Soon Rita, a woman who is expecting a child from him, comes to Andrei. The year is 1914. Student Andrei Startsov arrived in Germany shortly before the outbreak of the First World War. Due to the outbreak of the war, he cannot get to his homeland and lives in the town of Bischofsberg. In Germany, he became friends with the artist Kurt Van (Winfried Glatzeder), a person to him in spirit. But with the beginning of the war, Kurt recoiled from his friend Andrei, he felt that from now on they had nothing to talk about

Under en steinhimmel (Under a Stone Sky; Russian: Under the Stone Sky) is a Soviet-Norwegian war film directed by Knut Andersen, Igor Maslennikov, and Stanislav Rostotsky. The film is a fictionalized portrayal of historical events. The film tells the story of people that moved into the mine shafts at Bjørnevatn in eastern Finnmark county, Norway during the Second World War. They sought to escape the evacuation and burning of Finnmark. During the winter of 1944, the mines had a population between 2,000 and 3,000. They faced the danger of the German forces hearing about this and taking action before the Red Army managed to drive them out of the area

Secret City" is a Soviet feature film directed by Mikhail Yuzovsky, released in 1974 at the M. Gorky Film Studio (Yalta branch). Pioneer Andrei Belov is entrusted with the forge, and the boy automatically becomes one of the most respected people in the camp, the leader in the “privileged” ward No. 7 among aspiring writers and guitarists. Borya Sokolov, the namesake of the famous football player, is being placed in the same ward. The boy is mistaken for his son, which is facilitated by Boris's new boots. Taking the bait of their own imagination, bugler Andrei Belov and guitarist Vasnetsov boycott Boris. The events take place in a pioneer camp on the Black Sea coast, on the eve of a traditional war game codenamed “Secret City”, Andrey discovers that the forge is missing, which makes significant changes to the well-thought-out plan for holding the. lightning. A film about the life of a pioneer camp. Perhaps the plot of the film is somewhat overloaded with events - there is a detailed depiction of an absurd quarrel between teenagers, ending in the birth of a strong friendship, and a military game of “secret city” (hence the name of the film), and much more. film and do not affect its merits. And the advantages are obvious - they are in subtle observations of the psychology of children, and in the general atmosphere of joy in which the children, and in good humor, and in the abundance of music and songs performed by the famous pioneer choir named after V. Ring of Bright Water is a 1969 British comedy-drama film directed by Jack Couffer and starring Bill Travers and Virginia McKenna. It is a story about a Londoner and his pet otter living on the Scottish coast. The story is fictional, but is adapted from the 1960 autobiographical book of the same name by Gavin Maxwell. It featured the stars of Born Free (1966), another film about a relationship between humans and a wild animal. Graham Merrill passes a pet shop on his daily walks about London, and takes an interest in an otter (specifically, a male river otter) he sees in the shop window; eventually, he buys the animal and names him Mijbil or "Mij" for short. The otter wreaks havoc in his small flat, and together they leave London for a rustic cottage overlooking the sea on the west coast of Scotland. There they as beachcombers, and make the acquaintance of Dr. Mary MacKenzie from the nearby village, and her dog Johnny. Mij ​​and Johnny play in the water and bound across the fields together. One episode involves Graham trying to find eels for Mij, which is very difficult because during the winter the eels swim in deeper waters, making it tough to fish them out. Also, no fishmonger in town carries eels

Through the fates of the heroes, the film tells about the life of the Podolsk village during the years of Soviet power - collectivization in the village, where from time immemorial everyone was accustomed to working only for their own farm, about the war years, when many quiet people showed miracles of heroism, and everyone's favorites became Nazi puppets, about the post-war recovery of the economy destroyed by the enemies. About the life of the Ukrainian village over fifty years - from the days of the revolution and civil war to the present. The authors treat their heroes with love and respect, simple rural workers who drove out the landowners, defended Soviet power in the fight against enemies, and restored the economy destroyed by the war. Several generations pass before the viewer, and the main thing is passed on from generation to generation - love for the Soviet Motherland, for the land, for working for the good of the people. Stanislav Rassadin in the magazine “Soviet Screen” (No. 5, 1975) gave a devastatingly sarcastic review of the film, analyzing individual scenes that were in no way linked into one plot, the characters’ characters and their motives were not revealed, and he saw the main reason for the film’s failure as the inability to fit the epic canvas of the novel into an hour of screen time

name_original: KLK an PTX - Die Rote Kapelle
web_summary: The is dedicated to the activities of the residencies of the Main Intelligence Directorate of the General Staff of the Red Army in Western Europe, united under the general name “Red Chapel”, primarily residencies in Paris and Brussels. The group was led by Leopold Trepper, also known as Jean Gilbert. The film does not completely correspond to historical facts. For example, the action takes place almost exclusively in Paris, whereas in reality the main center of the intelligence network was Brussels. In particular, “Kent” was constantly in Brussels and was the de facto curator of the Belgian Red Chapel group. Makarov also lived permanently in Brussels. The fate of “Kent” (Anatoly Gurevich) does not correspond to historical truth. Probably based on these considerations, “Kent”, who currently lives (according to the plot of the ) in Paris, was renamed “Grinevich” (Anatoly Gurevich actually lived in Russia and died in 2009 in St. Petersburg). Mikhail Makarov is named Sergei in the film. “Kent” was arrested in Marseilles, Makarov in Brussels

Great Patriotic War. From the camp of the Belarusian partisans to the neighboring partisan camp, where there is a doctor, the sledding Griboed, the barely walking wounded Levchuk and the seriously wounded bedridden partisan Tikhonov, as well as the radio operator Klava, who is nine months pregnant, go on a cart. All roads are blocked by Nazi patrols; having encountered one of them and having accepted a battle in which Tikhonov dies, the partisans manage to escape. But a punitive squad is on their trail. The partisans take refuge in the threshing floor of a burned village, surrounded by Germans. Here Klava gives birth to a boy. The Germans surround the threshing floor and the battle begins again; only Levchuk and the newborn baby leave the partisans alive. But the Nazi punitive forces do not stop pursuing... In the footsteps of a handful of heroes, a fascist detachment literally moves day and night. This pursuit does not look like a pursuit, familiar from many about the war, but persecution (especially since among those retreating there is a woman with a child). and when only one fighter remains alive, saving the child, the squad of punitive forces chases after him, it seems, with even greater ferocity. The film tells about a girl who grew up in an orphanage, not knowing her own mother. Suddenly, she receives an old letter that her mother wrote many years ago. She decides to visit Moscow to meet her mother. Olga Vasilyeva, a young woman raised in an orphanage and studying at a vocational school, is determined to find the mother she has never met. Olga’s only clue is a letter from her mother, kept in her file at the orphanage. During her vacation, she travels from Sverdlovsk to Moscow, where the return address on the letter leads. At this address s Elena Alexeyevna, a ballet teacher, married to a professor at a Moscow technical institute. Although she warmly welcomes Olga, they quickly discover that Elena is not her mother; she simply shares the same name as Olga’s mother. Despite this, Elena sympathizes with Olga and offers to help her in her, inviting her to visit anytime

By order of Hitler, a large-scale offensive is planned to be organized against partisan detachments. Trust (Finnish: Luottamus; Russian: Doverie, romanized: Doverie) is a 1976 Finnish-Soviet historical drama film directed by Edvin Laine and Viktor Tregubovich. The film portrays the events leading up to the Finnish Declaration of Independence from Russia in 1917 and especially the role of Soviet leader Vladimir Lenin in them. The main roles are played by Kirill Lavrov as Lenin and Vilho Siivola as P. E. Svinhufvud. Edvin Laine received the state film artist award for the film, and Vilho Siivola received the Jussi Award for best actor. At the Riga Film Festival in 1977, the film was awarded a special jury prize for artistic merit in depicting the beginning stages of peaceful coexistence between two neighboring countries. After completion, the film was shown in schools as an educational film, but it did not do very well in cinemas. According to the current general perception, it strongly represents the spirit of the era of Finlandization between Finland and the Soviet Union. Trust takes place at the end of December 1917, when the Finnish delegation has traveled to St. Petersburg to seek recognition for the Finland's independence. Finnish Prime Minister P. E. Svinhufvud with diplomats Carl Enckell and Gustaf Idman has to decide whether to seek recognition of independence from the Bolshevik government, and Bolshevik leader V. I. Lenin has to choose accordingly whether to recognize the independence of bourgeois Finland. The main part of the plot consists of flash scenes, which on the one hand describe the central events of Finland's struggle for autonomy and independence, and on the other hand the shaping of Lenin's nationality policy and personal relationship with Finland in the years 1899–1917

Eleven-year-old Tima has many friends, but he does not have a mother, and his father is a stern, taciturn police colonel who spends all his time at work and almost does not communicate with his son. And although Tima has a caring grandmother, the boy still feels lonely. One day, Tim brings a real lion to his house, which escaped from the local circus. I told my father about this by phone. Local police were scrambling to find the predator. Having arrived, the father immediately decided to shoot the lion, but Tim came to the defense of his new friend. In an environment of mortal danger, the father realized that his son would not allow a strong, but defenseless lion to be killed: “we are responsible for those we have tamed.” And this is his father’s upbringing: the responsibility and kindness of the son shown at a critical moment evokes the father’s respect for his son’s behavior and allows him to realize that Tim has grown up and, if he shoots, he will lose his son. Soon the tamers arrived and took the lion, and father and son felt that they had become much closer to each other

“The Mattei Case” (Italian: Il Caso Mattei) is a 1972 Italian investigative film directed by Francesco Rosi. The film was awarded the Palme d'Or prize at the 25th Cannes Film Festival (together with Elio Petri's The Working Class Goes to Heaven), and Gian Maria Volonte's acting received a special mention.

Twelve-year-old Susanne talks about ants in class. She brought a terrarium with her to illust this. When the students get out of the heat during the lecture, everyone rushes out of the classroom. The terrarium is destroyed and many insects are trampled. Because Susanne prefers to focus on insects instead of important subjects like mathematics, the other children mock her. While her classmates are having fun on the beach, Susanne goes angry and sad and then visits an old lock keeper to whom she tells her woes. Then a magpie appears who wanted to steal a ring from a wooden box from the lock keeper. The old man explains to Susanne that the ring is a “carbuncle” that can comfort a person. You can trust the ring with everything and show it your own world so that the ring can learn. With beautiful things the ring would glow and with ugly things it would turn black. The old man says that he used to use the ring himself, but that it no longer fits old people. Susanne is happy about the ring and begins to show her her world. First, Susanne the ring who her parents are. The day her school is on the “carbuncle’s” learning. She makes sure that the ring also gets a lot of the difficult mathematics. A short time later she manages to solve a difficult math problem that no one else in the class knew. The teacher praises her and she gets an A in math for the first time. In the afternoon, Susanne goes on a motorboat trip with her father when the engine suddenly breaks down. Susanne wants the engine to run again, and it actually works again afterwards. Susanne now believes that the ring actually has magical powers. In the evening she dreams that she gets all A's on her report card. After a subsequent dream carousel ride with her insects, Susanne marries her classmate Andreas in a dream. The day the children play a circus on the beach. Susanne is once again excluded from this, but wants to play along. She changes one of Andreas' magic tricks so that it doesn't go as planned, and Andreas is angry with her. At the end of the circus, the children release some New Year's Eve rockets, which, according to Susanne's wish, actually cause some damage. The children flee from the adults running up, only Susanne stays and takes everything on herself. Andreas is impressed by Susanne's courage and they both become friends. On a boat trip, Susanne can convince Andreas of the ring's magical power. However, when the ring is supposed to help him win a soccer game, it fails: at the last minute, the opposing team wins and Andreas turns away from Susanne. The day, Susanne proves to him that the ring works: she wishes for a camel to appear. She mounts it and it gallops away without her being able to get off in time. Andreas is left alone and goes looking for Susanne, but cannot find her. Susanne reappears on her own Eventually. Relieved, Andreas begins to tease Susanne. Susanne loses the ring, which is carried away by the magpie. Susanne and Andreas are with the old lock keeper. Susanne confesses to him that she lost the ring, but the lock keeper is not angry. He explains to her that everyone comes to a point in life where they need a “carbuncle”. The magpie probably needed the ring right now. Susanne then thinks about what kind of worries a magpie might have
"The Rock", a film directed by Vardan Achemyan in 1973. It is the adaptation of Vrtanes Papazyan's play of the same name.

The film takes place in Baku at the beginning of the 20th century. The life of an industrial city is shown - the chaos of the capitalist world. The struggle of social classes and estates, the exploitation of workers, the disintegration of the bourgeois family, in which the thirst for money dominates all feelings - these are the main social problems on which the plot is based. Major oil industrialist Markos Alimyan bequeaths his property to his eldest son Sumbat, who did not return to his father’s house after studying, accusing his father of amassing wealth by robbing people. Over time, Sumbat, under the influence of money, is drawn into business, forgetting all his high aspirations and betraying his views. The youngest son Mikael, whom his father did not send to study, led a dissolute, wasteful life, but under the influence of noble love he corrected himself and was able to change his life

The Taste of Halva" is a Soviet fairy tale film directed by Pavel Arsenov with oriental motifs, the background story of the adventures of Khoja Nasreddin, where he appears as a teenager. Filmed in 1975 at the Yalta branch of the M. Gorky Film Studio. The film is dedicated to the memory of the creator of the literary image of Nasreddin, writer Leonid Solovyov. For many years, the great emir of Bukhara has not known happiness - he has lost the magical taste of halva, and now life for him is as sour as lemon. And in the house of the poor potter Shir-Mamed there is happiness: he miraculously had a little son, and his name is Nasreddin. And who would know what this young rogue and wit is capable of?! All of Bukhara has already heard about Nasreddin’s tricks! emir? The filming took place in Eastern Crimea; the Bukhara set was built by the prop shop of the Yalta Film Studio under the direction of artist Nikolai Emelyanov

According to the director, Anton killed Zosya, because “rolling deeper and deeper down the slope, he realized that he could not take her with him, breaking her internal integrity, inducing her to go down to the same level as himself.” The girl, our heroine, is a village girl. She is a “social product of the Soviet era.” She was raised right. Of course, religion was prohibited, but, nevertheless, a certain religiosity is present in it, which means these are completely different parameters of spirituality. The boy, our main character, is a city boy. He grew up without parents and had to survive on the streets. The Deluge was a series of mid-17th-century military campaigns in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. In a stricter sense, the term refers to the Swedish invasion and occupation of the Commonwealth as a theatre of the Second Northern War (1655–1660) only; in Poland and Lithuania this period is called the Swedish Deluge (Polish: potop szwedzki, Lithuanian: švedų tvanas, Swedish: svenska syndafloden), or less commonly the Russo–Swedish Deluge (Polish: Potop szwedzko-rosyjski) due to the simultaneous Russo-Polish War.

Crime" is a Soviet cinematic duology (the first film is “Intolerance", the second film is “Deception” in two episodes) directed by Evgeny Tashkov, filmed in 1976 at the Mosfilm film studio in the genre of detective-psychological drama. Both are box office leaders; in the year of their premiere, they were watched by 27 million and 23.3 million viewers, respectively. Graduation class student Vladimir Karetnikov (Yushkov) was detained while committing a double theft. In court, the school director Lidiya Andreevna (Medvedeva) and one of the teachers Pavel Sergeevich (Ozerov) give personal guarantee for the young man. The trial is limited to a suspended sentence. personality.” He condemns his son not for the lack of any ethical standards, but for his pettiness in choosing a goal and lack of firmness in achieving it. With the direct connivance of his father, the young man continues to ignore the demands of his teachers and morally and physically humiliate those around him, including his friend Nadya Kovrova (Gabets). One day, teacher Pavel Sergeevich comes to the girl’s defense. Over time, becoming increasingly disillusioned with her former friend Volodya, Nadya becomes romantically interested in an intelligent teacher. Young Karetnikov, intolerant of disobedience, demands that the girl maintain her relationship. Nadya refuses him. At the moment of a quarrel, Pavel Sergeevich comes to her aid. Enraged, Vladimir hits the teacher with a knife. Pavel Sergeevich survives, but is in serious condition in the hospital. Grigory Vasilyevich Karetnikov is informed about his son’s new crime. He is trying to impose on the investigation and all participants in the incident the version of a fight motivated by youthful jealousy. His actions are in vain: Vladimir is sentenced to five years in a maximum security colony

Adoption (Hungarian: Örökbefogadás) is a 1975 Hungarian drama film directed by Márta Mészáros. It was entered into the 25th Berlin International Film Festival, where it won the Golden Bear. The film was also selected as the Hungarian entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 48th Academy Awards, but was not accepted as a nominee. The film tells the story of Kata, a 42-year-old female factory worker who s alone near a residential care facility for abandoned children. She has a relationship with a married man, with whom she would like to have a child. He declines the offer, and the woman becomes interested in Anna, a girl from the children's. She helps Anna marry her boyfriend, and decides to adopt a baby from the orphanage

During the Second World War and the occupation of Serbia, in the multi-ethnic Banat village, there was a stratification of the inhabitants on a national basis. Lexi is a Volksdeutscher, a drunkard and a disreputable peasant who waited his five minutes to put on a uniform and parade with a rifle. Since there is a law that for every killed German, 50 locals are shot, Lexi uses the fear of the people to make himself important and scary. However, his wife Anika makes fun of him because he didn't manage to get a better property like other Germans. Marko, a local, comes up with a plan to get rid of Lexi's reign of terror. Through Annika, he persuades Lexi to self-injure himself in order to be temporarily incapacitated for war, thereby avoiding command to the Eastern Front, and in return receiving compensation from the locals

M. Plisetskaya. The sets and costumes were created by Valery Levental. “Office Romance” is a Soviet two-part feature film filmed at the Mosfilm studio in 1977, a lyrical tragicomedy directed by Eldar Ryazanov. It was the box office leader in 1978 - then it was watched by over 58 million viewers.

Destiny" is a 1977 Soviet wide-screen film produced at the Mosfilm studio. Sequel to the film "Earthly Love". Based on the novel of the same name by Pyotr Proskurin. The Great Patriotic War begins. Zakhar Deryugin goes to the front, but is captured there. Zahara’s sister, Katerina, finds herself under occupation along with her patients. Having failed to obtain agreement to cooperate, the Germans shoot her. Katerina’s husband, Bryukhanov, heads the underground regional party committee and partisan detachments. Vanya, Deryugin's eldest son, dies from a fascist bullet while trying to escape, when he and the other teenagers are being taken to be sent to Germany. Euphrosyne, sets fire to her house along with the drunken officers and soldiers stationed there who have fallen asleep In response, the German command is preparing a punitive action. The Age of Innocence (Russian: Minors, romanized: Nesovershennoletnie, also called Minors) is a 1976 Soviet film directed by Vladimir Rogovoy and written by Edward Topol. It is not based on the novel The Age of Innocence, instead being a juvenile delinquency film set in the contemporary Soviet Union. Russian teenager Zhenya Prokhorov returns from military service and his friend Kostya from a corrective labor colony. They try to stay out of trouble and find a place in the world. Two friends return to their hometown at the same time: Zhenya from the army and Kostya from a correctional colony, where he served time for a drunken brawl. Together, they confront a gang of hooligans who extort money from children and rob drunken passersby. After a few scuffles, Zhenya realizes that fighting alone won’t solve the problem, especially as he notices his 11-year-old nephew, Shurka, beginning to fall under the gang's influence

Cartouche (French cartouche - “ornamental edging in the form of a scroll with folded corners”, from Italian cartoccio “paper bundle, little bag, bag for a powder charge”, which goes back to Italian carta - paper) - in architecture and decorative arts - a motif in the form of a shield framed with curls or "half-unfolded, often with torn or notched edges of a roll of paper, scroll” on which a coat of arms, emblem or inscription can be placed. Cartouches arose during the Renaissance at the turn of the 15th-16th centuries.

This Doesn’t Concern Me..." is a Soviet full-length color feature film produced at the Lenfilm studio in 1976 by director Herbert Rappaport. The film can be considered as the final part of Herbert Rappaport's trilogy about the work of the OBKhSS with Alexander Zbruev in the lead roles. However, in the first two (“Two tickets to an afternoon session” and “Circle”), Zbruev’s hero’s name is Alexander Aleshin, and in the film “This Doesn’t Concern Me...” - Sergei Shubnikov. The director of the weaving factory, Kartashov, died in a car accident. Young specialists invited to the plant: psychologist Petrov, an energetic guy from the provinces who is making his own way in life, and sociologist Burtseva, a young woman who has experienced a personal drama in the past, are studying the problem: why experienced, proactive workers often leave the enterprise and move to other factories in the city. After studying the causes and circumstances with the help of the party committee secretary Konstantinov, they will present the results and convince the administration of the need to have their own sociological laboratory.

The Common Man (French: Dupont Lajoie) is a 1975 French drama film directed by Yves Boisset and produced by Sofracima. It was entered into the 25th Berlin International Film Festival, where it won the Silver Bear - Special Jury Prize. In the United States, the film was released under the title Rape of Innocence. Georges Lajoie is a cafe owner in Paris, on Place d'Aligre. The Lajoies and their son Léon, a high school graduate, are leaving with their new caravan to spend their summer vacation, as they do every year, on the Provençal coast, at the "Camping-Caravaning Beau-soleil" run by Loulou, a Pied-Noir. There, the Lajoies meet the Schumachers, bailiffs in Strasbourg, and the Colins, underwear sellers at the markets. These good Frenchmen from the North spout off platitudes, notably about the supposed laziness of "people from the South," but nevertheless want to make friends with the Vigorellis, Italians who are new to the campsite. Vigorelli is a construction site manager and considers the new buildings constructed by Loulou for vacationers, using the low-wage labor of Algerian workers housed in a shack, to be "crap." But Vigorelli and Loulou speak Arabic and respect the immigrant workers for their hard work

Decoy ducks are a breed group of domestic ducks that are similar in appearance to wild mallard ducks and are used for hunting waterfowl. Hunting with a decoy duck is a traditional Russian hunt, in which the hunter places decoys on the water (on a river, lake, swamp, sometimes just a puddle), and he himself hides in a shelter (hut) made from available camouflage material (spruce spruce branches, dry grass, reeds).

“Immortals” (Romanian: Nemuritorii) is a 1974 film by Romanian director Sergiu Nicolaescu in the genre of historical adventure drama. The picture, based on fiction, describes a series of events that occurred after the murder of the ruler of Wallachia and commander Mihai the Brave.
Living Free is a 1972 British drama film, written by Millard Kaufman and directed by Jack Couffer. It starred Nigel Davenport, Susan Hampshire and Geoffrey Keen.
