Salty is an American family comedy-drama film directed by Ricou Browning in his feature-length directorial debut. It was written by Ricou Browning and Jack Cowden, who had previously written the 1963 film Flipper and its subsequent television series together.

Market merchant Karol Bulyak bought an old suitcase, which contained a strange guitar, but Bulyak, going on an excursion abroad, did not have time to examine the musical instrument. During an excursion to Italy, he learned that the strange guitar was the famous “Laura,” worth a million dollars, which French soldiers had once taken to the east.

Moulin Rouge is a 1952 British historical romantic drama film directed by John Huston from a screenplay he co-wrote with Anthony Veiller, based on the 1950 novel of the same name by Pierre La Mure, and produced by John and James Woolf. The film follows artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec as he navigates the bohemian subculture of 19th-century Paris, centered around the Moulin Rouge, a burlesque venue. It was screened at the 14th Venice International Film Festival, where it won the Silver Lion. The film stars José Ferrer, Zsa Zsa Gabor, Suzanne Flon, Eric Pohlmann, Colette Marchand, Christopher Lee, Peter Cushing, Katherine Kath, Theodore Bikel, and Muriel Smith. In 1890 Paris, crowds gather at the Moulin Rouge as artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec finishes a bottle of cognac while sketching the dancers. Regular patrons arrive: singer Jane Avril teases Henri, dancers La Goulue and Aicha argue, and owner Maurice Joyant offers Henri free drinks for a promotional poster. After closing, Henri reveals his 4-foot-6-inch (137 cm) stature. A flashback that, as a child, he injured his legs in a fall, which never healed due to a genetic disorder from his parents being first cousins
Benji is a 1974 American family film, the first in a series about the adventures of a dog named Benji. Next up is “For the Love of Benji.

Budenovka (its official names are winter headdress, winter helmet or simply helmet) is a uniform headdress for military personnel of the Workers 'and Peasants' Red Army (RKKA), a cloth helmet with a visor and folding sides that cover the ears and neck when lowered. In Soviet military-historical literature it was argued that the Budenovka (as well as an overcoat with transverse flaps - “conversations” and other elements of the new military uniform of the Red Army) were created in 1918-1919 specifically for the Red Army.

Pavel Pavlovich Goryaev is a middle-aged actor. For many years he has been playing leading roles in the provincial theater. The director of the play based on the play, which was written with Goryaev in mind, takes a young actor to play his role. Goryaev initially falls into despair, leaves the theater, and turns to friends. After some time, he rethinks what happened and realizes that the time has come to leave the stage with dignity. Semyon Laskin: “I watched the bad film “The Tale of an Unknown Actor”” and immediately remembered my Sovetsk - a good theater. And I regretted that I did not go on any trip with the troupe. I touched a strange life. Clean. Beyond ambition. And selfless. I would like to write about this - theater, actors, work, performances in front of 10 old women, conversations...” As Natalya Zelenko noted in the publication “The Moviegoer’s Companion”: “In this film, actors play actors. The film opens for the audience the door behind the scenes of the theater - the same door on which usually hangs a stern sign: “No entry to outsiders”... Three acting destinies, three different characters. The authors do not judge their heroes - they simply invite you to think about who is happier and why

Everyone Dies Alone / Alone in Berlin (Original title: Jeder stirbt für sich allein) is a 1976 West German drama film adapted from the Hans Fallada novel Every Man Dies Alone. The book was based on the story of two ordinary Germans, Otto and Elise Hampel, who committed acts of civil disobedience against the Third Reich, were caught and sentenced to death. The film takes place in Berlin in 1940, during World War II as Adolf Hitler is at the height of his power. Anna and Otto Quangel, a working class couple, in Berlin in simple circumstances and are not particularly interested in politics. Then, their only son is killed in action during the Battle of France and as they grieve for their son, the desire to resist the Nazi regime grows within them. When a Jewish neighbor is also killed, Anna decides to join the German Resistance. She begins writing very personal flyers on postcards, which she at first alone and then with her husband, leaves in public places and slips into mailboxes. The two are discovered, arrested and eventually sentenced to death. Otto Quangel commits suicide in the courtroom with a cyanide pill; his wife is executed two months later. The Lexikon des deutschen published in 1995 by German publisher Reclam called the film Vohrer's most challenging work, stating further, "albeit somewhat sentimental, but without sensationalist moments, this film adaptation comes near Fallada's original. Especially haunting is the focused and unadorned performance by Hildegard Knef

Parade (French parade, Spanish parada, from Latin parāre ‘to prepare’), military parade or naval parade - the passage of troops in a solemn march with or without military equipment, it is also the formation of personnel or equipment on significant dates. A military parade is held, as a rule, on official holidays, celebrations of state and military significance, after the completion of major military exercises, as well as during the funeral of military personnel, leaders of the state or country, and other persons at whose burial military honors are required.

Strange Woman" is a Soviet two-part melodrama filmed in 1977 by director Yuli Raizman. The main role in the film was played by Irina Kupchenko. By profession, she is a legal adviser, married to a successful employee of the USSR Ministry of Foreign Trade. However, there has long been coldness and indifference in the family, even with a teenage son, and attempts to find something strong on a trip with her husband to Berlin, in an attempt to start an affair with a cybernetics scientist, fail. Evgenia left Moscow, her family, her son and came to a provincial town, to her mother, devoting herself to work and people who needed her help Later, an unknown young man appears who cannot without her At first, Evgenia is negative and suspicious of him. she begins to understand that this is the person she has been waiting for all her life. Murder on the Orient Express is a 1974 British mystery film directed by Sidney Lumet, produced by John Brabourne and Richard Goodwin, and based on the 1934 novel of the same name by Agatha Christie. The film has an all-star , and features the Belgian detective Hercule Poirot (Albert Finney), who is asked by a railway director (Martin Balsam) to investigate the murder of an American business tycoon (Richard Widmark) aboard the Orient Express train. The various suspects are portrayed by Lauren Bacall, Ingrid Bergman, Sean Connery, John Gielgud, Jean-Pierre Cassel, Vanessa Redgrave, Michael York, Rachel Roberts, Jacqueline Bisset, Anthony Perkins, Denis Quilley, Colin Blakely, and Wendy Hiller. The screenplay is by Paul Dehn. The film was a commercial and critical success. Bergman won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, and the film received five other nominations at the 47th Academy Awards: Best Actor (Finney), Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Original Score, Best Cinematography, and Best Costume Design

In a Turkmen village, young people Enver and Dondi love each other, and after progressing from school they plan to go to university together. But the girl’s father forbids her to go to Ashgabat to study. He protects his daughter in every possible way in public life; in her opinion, the girl should in accordance with the traditions of her fathers and grandfathers. Enver goes to the city alone and goes to study. At this time, Dondi's parents forcibly marry her to someone else - not a poor student, but someone who can ensure her well-being and pay the bride price. Enver, having learned about Dondi’s parents’ plans to marry her off to someone else, trying to quickly get a bride price for his beloved, is lost in life’s circumstances: he finds himself in the company of speculators and thieves. He is saved by the arrival of Dondi, who, after a month of hateful marriage, secretly runs away to Ashgabat, where she begins working as a teacher in a kindergarten and at the same time enters preparatory courses at the university. In response to the demand of her father, who came for her, to return to the village, to her husband, the girl finds the courage to give a decisive refusal. It is noted that the film has many similarities with the film by director Khojakuli Narliev’s older brother, “Be able to say “no!”,” released a year later, but this film “having repeated some plot lines, at the same time introduced a fundamentally new motive.” At the same time, the film is broader than the filmed story: The authors of the film (director Kh. D. Narliev and screenwriter S. Listov) sought to approach the capacity of prose and achieve analytical research. Kh. D. Narliev takes the film’s problems to a higher, philosophical level of solution. It is important for him to find the root causes, the roots of the relapse of social psychology, incompatible with the socialist way of life. “Whiteout,” according to the director, is, first of all, a person’s own moral blindness. The film's dramaturgy seeks a dramatic beginning in the psychology and mental make-up of the characters. The film by Kh. D. Narliev is characterized by a large volume of life observations. The leading, formative element in the plot was the conflict of moral choice, embodying the youth theme, moreover, in its philosophical understanding. It made it possible to contrast the new life with the patriarchal antiquity, in particular, to highlight the facet of the problem of women's emancipation

A truly beautiful plot is rare, like a gift of fate... There was Mark Donskoy, who, at the very end of his life, shot the completely unnoticed masterpiece “The Orlov Spouses”... The troubled family life of the Orlov spouses - the drunkard and rowdy Grishka Orlov and his wife Matryona, who tolerates all his antics, radically changes, when during the outbreak of an epidemic they become orderlies of a cholera barracks... The time of hard and dangerous work turns out to be the happiest in life for both of them and changes their worldview and character. What attracted me to the cycle of Kazan and Nizhny Novgorod stories created by the writer at the end of the last century? The author’s great love for justice, an ardent desire to find the truth in life... In less than two hours of screen time, we had to convey the complex and instructive, tragic and at the same time full of deep social optimism story of the Orlovs. It was necessary to show people who are accustomed to everything, who have become accustomed to the abomination of their way of life, and to declare that these are good, but unhappy people, and it is not their fault that they are like this, but the social system that existed at that time

Captain Blood (French: Le capitan, lit. 'The Captain'; Italian: Il capitano del re, lit. 'The King's Captain') is a 1960 French–Italian swashbuckler film directed by André Hunebelle and starring Jean Marais, Bourvil, Elsa Martinelli and Lise Delamare. It is based on a novel by Michel Zévaco. The story unfolds in France in the early 17th century, with Louis XIII just coming of age while his mother, Marie de' Medici, continues to rule with her, Concino Concini, who is the prime minister. Concini, aided by his ambitious wife Leonora Dori, seeks to consolidate power through any means necessary, even resorting to crime and treason. He spreads terror across the land, particularly in the southwestern provinces, orchestrating attacks to weaken the nobility. However, high-ranking lords conspire to overthrow Concini and place the Duke Charles of Angoulême, who is excluded from the regular royal succession, on the throne. Among these nobles is François de Capestang, a brave knight determined to fight for justice and protect his king's crown, as well as the life of Gisèle d'Angoulême, whom he owes a debt of gratitude for saving him in battle

Dead Mountaineer's Hotel (Estonian: "Hukkunud Alpinisti" hotell, Russian: Hotel "At the Dead Mountaineer") is a 1979 Soviet era Estonian film directed by Grigori Kromanov and based on the 1970 novel Dead Mountaineer's Hotel by Arkady and Boris Strugatsky, who also wrote the screenplay. The film was directed by Grigori Kromanov, with his wife Irena Veisaitė acting as assistant director while taking a sabbatical year from university. It was filmed between 1978 and 1979 in Kazakhstan, and set in a fictional western country. Lead actor Uldis Pūcītis, who did not speak Estonian, had his lines dubbed by Estonian actor and theater teacher Aarne Üksküla. Due to an anonymous call, Inspector Glebsky travels to the hotel "Dead Mountaineer's." This hotel is located in a mountainous region of a secluded valley in a European nation. Simply put, the hotel's name, "Dead Mountaineer's," refers to the fact that a climber perished here after falling from a cliff. He left only his faithful dog behind – a St. Bernard called Lel. In the hotel there is a rather bleak portrait of the climber near which faithful Lel likes to sleep
“Certificate of Poverty” is a 1978 Soviet feature film directed by Samvel Gasparov based on the Weiner brothers’ story “A Watch for Mr. ” The film premiered in January 1979.

Excavations of an ancient settlement in Kazakhstan are coming to an end. On the last day of the expedition, the curator of the Republican Museum, Zimin, finds several women’s jewelry, including the “Procession of Golden Animals” tiara.

Life Is Beautiful (Italian: La vita è bella, Russian: Life is Beautiful, romanized: Zhizn prekrasna, also known as Betrayed) is a 1979 Italian-Soviet romantic drama directed by Grigory Chukhray. The action takes place in an unnamed country (in foreign versions of the film the country is Portugal during Salazar's reign), ruled by a military junta which violently suppresses any free thought. Antonio Murillo is a former military pilot who was dismissed from the army for refusing to sink a ship loaded with refugees. Now he drives a taxi and periodically becomes a witness to the despotism of the authorities. His girlfriend Mary, waitress, is a member of an underground movement fighting against the dictatorship. Antonio, for all his dislike of the junta is not interested in politics, his dream is to save money and to become a pilot again, and to own a private plane. But once he drives a man on his taxi, who turns out to be on the side of the opposition. This causes him to come to the attention of the special services. Because of that provocateur he ends up going to prison, where there are several members of the underground and ends up subjected to torture. Through ingenuity and mechanic skills he manages to save the life of underground fighters, disrupting the arranged provocation caused by the warden, and then organize an escape from prison. Together with Maria, Antonio in a stolen taxi gets away from the police, and then uses a hijacked plane to leave the country

Long Distance Running Tactics" is a Soviet feature film (1978). The premiere took place on July 16, 1979. German Klimov, the author of the script, dedicated it to “the Znamensky brothers who died on the fronts of the Great Patriotic War.” Great Patriotic War. The doctor of the partisan detachment, Ivan Rusak - “a frail, bespectacled man with a kind smile” - goes with an escort to a neighboring detachment to take care of the wounded there: the doctor of this detachment, who went to deliver the child of a resident of a nearby village, was captured by the Germans along with his medical instruments. Ivan has not slept for several days and from time to time “switches off” from reality - he sleeps while walking, with his eyes open, ignoring the attempts of the guide to talk to him. Arriving at the detachment, Ivan meets his old friend, the national running champion Sergei Yartsev. Sergei is wounded, and Ivan quickly diagnoses his friend with gangrene. In a small fishing village on the shores of the Azov Sea, a fisheries inspector was killed during night duty. This circumstance became a serious reason for attracting the authorities and residents of the village to the problems of nature protection and restoration. In his film, L. Osyka turned to a modern theme. The plot, formally dedicated to the investigation of the murder of a fisheries inspector on the Sea of ​​Azov, makes it possible to address one of the most alarming and pressing problems of our day - the problem of environmental protection. The danger, the director believes, here lies primarily in the fact that people do not always understand the importance of everyone’s struggle for the purity of nature - and this is one of our main moral responsibilities today. Osyki’s film is a study of the life positions of its characters, a kind of debate on the screen

Babylon XX (Russian: “Babylon XX”, romanized: Vavilon XX; Ukrainian: “Babylon XX”, romanized: Vavilon XX) is a 1979 Soviet film directed by Ivan Mykolaichuk in his directorial debut and starring an ensemble including Mykolaichuk, Lyubov Polishchuk, and Les Serdyuk as peasants struggling to adapt to life within a commune led by Soviet sailor Klym Synytsia (played by Ivan Havryliuk). It is a loose film adaptation of the 1971 novel A Flock of Swans by Vasyl Zemliak, and depicts collectivization in the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic and the transition from capitalism to communism in Ukraine. Babylon XX had a troubled production history, with both a part-time film and a backdrop of Soviet repressions on Ukrainian freedom of expression; Ukrainian poetic cinema, the movement to which Babylon XX belonged, was formally banned, and A Flock of Swans itself had been threatened to be banned. The film's production took two years before premiering at the 1979 Kyiv International Film Festival "Molodist" to critical acclaim, being awarded the festival's main prize. Since its release, the film has come to be seen as one of the greatest Ukrainian of all time. It is tenth on the list of the 100 best in the history of Ukrainian cinema created by the National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre, and has been described as a classic of Ukrainian poetic cinema by the Ukrainian State Film Agency. In the early 1920s in Podolia, the village of Babylon has come under the government of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, but life has not changed significantly from the times of the Russian Empire. However, upheaval begins when Red Navy sailor and Babylon native Klym Synytsia (Ivan Havryliuk) arrives in the village, seeking to build communism and establish a commune. Noticing the amateur statues of deposed Tsar Nicholas II and his family, Synytsia destroys them with grenades, proclaiming "Polundra!" (the battle cry of the Soviet marines) as he does so

Heavy water - This term is usually used to refer to heavy hydrogen water, also known as deuterium oxide. Hydrogen heavy water has the same chemical formula as ordinary water, but instead of two atoms of the usual light isotope of hydrogen (protium), it contains two atoms of the heavy isotope of hydrogen - deuterium, and its oxygen is similar in isotopic composition to air oxygen.

After an accident and a pursuit of the Confectionery van, police officers discovered a unique chandelier from the 18th century in it. As a result of the examination, it is discovered that the pendants on the chandelier are made not of Bohemian crystal, but of phosphate glass produced at a glass factory on behalf of the museum. OBHSS begins an investigation into possible abuses related to the illegal trafficking of bronze and Bohemian crystal. Suddenly it turns out that the museum's order for the production of phosphate glass was overestimated by 10 times. The criminal, having replaced real pendants on the museum chandeliers with phosphate glass, wanted to take authentic Bohemian crystal from the USSR. Don't change horses in the middle of a stream is an aphorism that has entered the Russian language as a proverb, currently used in political advertising as a polysemiotic and synsematic contextual way of argumentation appealing to common sense. The film takes place during the Great Patriotic War. In a Belarusian town occupied by the Nazis, Baba Vera gathers orphans under her roof. Her house also serves as a meeting place for partisan contacts. German intelligence officer Erich, masquerading as former head teacher Roman Paskevich, begins checking this place, suspecting connections with the partisans. One of the underground members exposes Erich, but he manages to escape. Baba Vera tries to smuggle the children into the forest, but the Germans detain them and send them to a station where they are planned to be used as donors. As a result of an attempt to save the children, Baba Vera dies from the fire of the guards. In response, the partisans develop a plan to free the children. During the operation, Erich, who infiltd the detachment and tried to interfere with the partisans, also dies. Critic L. Avilova analyzed the film in the magazine “Soviet Screen”. She wrote that the image of Baba Vera, performed by the remarkable, in Avilova’s opinion, Belarusian actress Galina Makarova, embodies the audience’s idea of ​​the unbending courage and spiritual fortitude of the Soviet people. The acting of Andrei Tolubeev, who plays the role of Gestapo officer Erich, was also assessed positively. At the end of her article, the critic emphasized that “some episodes are drawn out, a number of storylines are not sufficiently developed dramatically,” but the creators of the film “succeeded in the main thing - they composed a stern and moving hymn to the people’s golden heart.” Critic F. Markova in the paper “Soviet Culture” also assessed the film positively, noting that it “some directorial constraint, a fear of deviating from the usual, the traditional

In the small provincial town of Okhansk, a young girl Nina Solomatina s with her mother. The father left his first family long ago and went to Moscow, where he has since d with his second wife and 12-year-old schoolboy son. Nina, who dreams of “training to become an artist,” comes to Moscow, but shamefully fails the entrance exams to a theater school. Having decided to try to enroll year, Nina remains in the capital. The father, who initially decided to help his daughter, who had grown up without him, rents a sepa apartment for Nina, where, according to his plans, her daughter will prepare for her new admission to the theater school and take preparatory courses. However, Nina is in no hurry to study; in her rented apartment, groups of acquaintances, unfamiliar and sometimes complete strangers constantly gather, music blares until late, young people dance wildly, despite the dissatisfaction of their neighbors. Sometimes Nina’s friend, the gypsy Karma, even spends the night there. At one of these parties, Nina accidentally met a young Muscovite Nikita, who at first somehow liked the funny, naive provincial girl, and even in a sepa apartment, where he decided to settle after a quarrel with his parents. Nina, having seriously fallen in love with Nikita and at the same time being confident in the reciprocity of feelings, plans to marry him. Nevertheless, Nina’s plans fail: Nikita pretty soon leaves her for a new fleeting hobby. I have to leave the apartment: my father promised that he rented the apartment for a year, but only paid the landlady for a month. The owner demands repayment of the debt, threatening to sue. A random acquaintance of the gypsy Karma helps Nina, sending her son to her so that he brings the required amount, and Nina practically leaves on the street. The girl has a hard time: she works at the Zarya company (nanny, au pair, courier). At the same time, she herself s in the school building, where the guard allows her to spend the night. However, Nina sends part of the money she earns to her mother in Okhansk, puts the money aside to return it to her father, not wanting to be in debt to him after the whole story with the apartment. On one of her official assignments, she ends up in the house of her former lover Nikita, where she needs to prepare everything for the festive banquet. Nikita is embarrassed by Nina's presence in his house, but Nina remains calm. After inviting her to a dance during a banquet, he threatens to tell her management that she stole money from their house. The amazed Nina leaves Nikita's house. Already on the street, Nikita catches up with her and asks for forgiveness, saying that Nina’s appearance awakened pleasant memories in him and now he cannot sleep peacefully. Nina tells Nikita that she is not angry with him, because her feelings for him have long burned out

Moscow mid-19th century. A middle-aged provincial businessman, Savva Gennadievich Vasilkov, falls in love with the local beauty Lidiya Yuryevna Cheboksarova. Wanting to get to know her, he asks his new acquaintance Telyatev to introduce himself as Cheboksarov. Telyatev and his friend Glumov decide to play a prank on Lydia’s mother Nadezhda Antonovna, who wants to get her rich son-in-law, and recommend Vasilkov as a millionaire gold miner from Siberia. Savva Gennadievich begins to visit the Cheboksarovs’ house, but his provincialism and Lydia’s intention, thanks to her beauty, to make up a brilliant match prevent them from finding a common language. Meanwhile, Nadezhda Antonovna receives from her husband about the need to sell his last estate to pay debts. She turns to the elderly Prince Kuchumov for help, who is also not indifferent to Lydia’s beauty, but the prince only makes promises instead of money. She hints to her daughter that she needs to find a rich husband, and Lydia first chooses Telyatev as the “victim”. However, he only counts on light flirting, but does not intend to get married. Then Lydia marries Vasilkov, who is in love with her. The Cheboksarovs continue to in grand style on credit. Savva is in for an unpleasant surprise - he finds out that the Cheboksarovs have a huge debt and that he will have to pay this debt. Vasilkov agrees, but on the condition that the Cheboksarovs stop living beyond their means, cut down their servants and move to a more modest house. Lydia considers such a proposal insulting, but is forced to agree. Having moved to a small house, she continues to show signs of favor to her former admirers - Telyatev and Prince Kuchumov in the hope of their financial support. Having heeded the persuasion of the “princeling” and his promise to give money, she decides to leave her husband and move to an old apartment. On the same day, she breaks up with her husband: Savva, returning, sees his wife flirting with Kuchumov and drives her away. The triumphant Lydia, encouraged by the assurances of the “princeling,” leaves the grief-stricken Savva

The Golden Fleece is in ancient Greek mythology the golden skin of a ram sent by the goddess of the clouds Nephele, or Hermes on the orders of Hera, or Zeus himself, on whose back the children of the Orkhomen king Athamas - Phrixus and Gella - went to the shores of Asia, fleeing the persecution of their stepmother Ino (or, according to another version of the myth, aunt Biadica). On the way, Gella fell into the sea, which was then named the Hellespont - “Sea of ​​Gella” (the modern Dardanelles Strait).

Lithuanian film heritage FAKTASFACTDirected byAlmantas GrikevičiusYears1980Duration96Original versionLithuanianSubtitlesEnglish, French, RussianAvailable formatsDCP, MP4, Blu-rayGenreDrama Creative team Written by Vytautas Žalakevičius Cinematography by Donatas Pečiūra Cast Algimantas Masiulis, Irena Marija Leonavičiūtė, Saulius Balandis, Juozas Budraitis, Donatas Banionis, Doloresa Kazragytė, Vaiva Mainelytė, Regimantas Adomaitis About the film Fact is a dramatization of the massacre in a Lithuanian village during World War II when the Nazis rounded up over 100 old men, women, and children accused of partisan activities and then torched the houses in which they were held. The hero of the film, swimmer Anton Dumbadze, tells the story of the Dumbadze swimming dynasty from Batumi - grandfather Durmishkhan and father Domenty. The head of the diving service of the Batumi seaport, who began his work by cleaning ships from mollusks and algae, Durmishkhan swam the way from Batumi to Poti, but no one believed the eccentric Batumi man who sat in an aquarium for weeks, challenging the famous English swimmer Thomas Winston, who swam across the English Channel. Having fallen into despair from the public's indifference to his record swim, Durmishkhan begins to drink too much and is hit to death by a train when a drunken Durmishkhan entered the tunnel. Domentiy, who regularly organized swimming competitions in Soviet Georgia, decided to repeat his father’s achievement, but became a victim of Stalinist repression due to the denunciation of his friend and also swimmer Odysseus Meskhi, who decided to take Domentiy’s sister Lala away from and get rid of his competitor. After Domentiy Dumbadze was arrested on the eve of the start of a record swim because his son threw a bust of Stalin into an aquarium, Meskhi marries Lala, and little Anton remains an orphan. Many years later, Anton, who works as an organizer of cultural events at the Tbilisi excursion bureau, who does not have even a fraction of the sporting qualities that Durmishkhan and Domentiy had, is going, at the request of a young assistant director who is shooting a documentary about the Dumbadze dynasty of swimmers, to do the same thing that his grandfather achieved and his father could not do - a swim from Batumi to Poti

The Rai family consists of four people: father, mother Shanti (Indrani Mukherjee) and two sons, Ajay and Vijay. While traveling on a ship they are caught in a fierce storm, which sinks the ship and separates the family. While Ajay and his mother are together, father Rai and similarly Vijay get separated. Wealthy Jagatnarayan Khanna (Pinchu Kapoor), rescues Rai, takes him and makes him his business partner. Years later, Rai's sons have grown up. Ajay (Rishi Kapoor) is a motor mechanic working in Pinto's garage, but he has bigger dreams. He is a liar and a swindler, who wants to make his dreams come true with a rich woman named Sheetal Khanna (Neetu Singh). Then there is Vijay (Rakesh Roshan), now known as Vikram. He works for Sheetal Khanna and hopes to marry her one day. But he is in a relationship with a beautiful woman named Mala. When Mala becomes pregnant, Vikram refuses to marry her. Soon after, Mala is killed and Vikram is blackmailed by a man named Prem (Prem Chopra). He claims to have seen Vikram killing Mala. When Vikram and Prem learn that Sheetal may marry Ajay, they join together and plot against her

“Death on Takeoff” is a Soviet feature film about the confrontation between Soviet and Western intelligence services, filmed in 1982 based on the book “Wolves Die in Traps” by former NKVD-KGB officer Andrei Solovyov. The TV premiere took place on February 14, 1983.

Speed" is a Soviet wide-screen color feature film produced at the Lenfilm Film Studio in 1983 by director Dmitry Svetozarov based on the book by Valery Musakhanov about auto racing, racers and cars. Grisha Yakovlev devotes all his free time to designing made racing cars and participating in auto racing, although outside the competition. His talent is noticed by a teacher at the Automotive Institute Lagutin and invites him to study and work. Lagutin’s department, where student Krista also works as a laboratory assistant, is designing and building a record-breaking turbojet racing car, the prototype of which recently killed Krista’s brother. Krista has been in love with Lagutin for a long time, and he finally answers her, but their romance ends as soon as it begins, due to the significant difference in age and different attitudes to life. Because of this disagreement, Krista ends up in Grisha’s bed, which she immediately regrets

The action takes place in the early 1980s in the USSR. Traffic police inspector Zykin was known among his colleagues as a disinterested person and an eccentric.

Vasily Buslaev, put in a barn by his mother at the slander of merchants, learns from the conversation of wanderers about the defeat and capture of the squad of Prince Gleb of Polotsk. Having gathered a gang, Vasily sets off from Novgorod in of the prince. Gleb's daughter Ksenia joins the gang. Warned that there are dashing people on a certain island, Vasily and his comrades land on the island and defeat the robbers, but their leader orders Xenia to be kidnapped, lures the gang into a cave, blocks the entrance and sails away. Vasily gets out of the cave, catches up with the robbers, defeats them and learns that Gleb and other Russians were sold into slavery in Constantinople and are in the quarries

Without Special Risk" is a Soviet feature film about police officers directed by Samvel Gasparov, filmed in 1983 at the Gorky Film Studio. This happens in Crimea and should not interfere with vacationers in any way. Pavlov about the acquisition of inexplicable extrasensory properties by a person in the process of space exploration. The action takes place in the future. The Space Security Service Commission, headed by Galbraith and Nikolsky, holds a meeting at which Professor Rogan is introduced to the materials of the investigation of paranormal “black traces.” Operative Cooper says that they first appeared in the Pamirs to the former space marine (i.e., space explorer) Kizimov, and subsequently appeared in other parts of the planet. Investigators watch footage of Kizimov’s interrogation and come to the conclusion that the “traces” are connected with a space disaster in the orbit of Uranus. After her, four Space Marines remained alive: Timur Kizimov, David Norton, Jean Loret and Eduard Yonge The commission is examining an unexplained artifact created by David Norton: a wand that works. like a television. In parallel with the interrogations, viewers are shown how, shortly before the meeting, security officer Frank Pauling trains at the training ground and discusses with the head of the training ground this very “black trail,” the development of the Solar system and the principles of operation of his service. The film begins with their conversation, and then the narrative returns to this episode in a flashback

1980, Vneshtorg organizes a horse auction for foreigners at the Progress stud farm, to which the great German horse lover Baron von Ritter comes. The Baron is interested in Sekunda, a descendant of a horse named Grabe, once taken as reparations after the war. But the director of the stud farm, Ermakov, who was a groom at that time, knows that under the name Grabe was his Nadezhda - in 1942, the Germans stole purebred breeding horses, including her, a direct successor of the line of the legendary horse Atlant, the horse of the Russian emperor. Nadezhda was returned in 1945, but according to the documents she was outbred to Grabe - someone replaced the breeding certificate. Ermakov, quarreling with representatives of Vneshtorg, does not want to sell horses, which foreigners buy for ridiculous money without documents confirming their pedigree. He realizes that it is no coincidence that Baron von Ritter is interested in Secunda, apparently he has a real tribal certificate of Nadezhda... but where did he get it, and who is the respectable businessman von Ritter? By chance, Ritter, who found himself at the stables, helps Ermakov deliver a difficult birth to one of the mares, after which they begin to trust each other - and a frank conversation takes place about the events of 1942. Ritter offers a deal, but Ermakov flatly refuses. Then - in 1942 he could not save Nadezhda, in 1945 he could not return her name, and now he is forced to sell her granddaughter Sekunda. At the auction, foreigners buy horses for 5-8 thousand dollars, and then Ermakov takes a risk and bluffs - he puts Sekunda up for auction for 100 thousand dollars, declaring that this is the granddaughter of Nadezhda, the great-granddaughter of Atlant, which is confirmed by captured documents with the baron’s seal. Ritter is forced to enter into a bargain, thereby admitting that Grabe was Nadezhda: the price soars to $3 million and the horse is removed from the auction. The film was sharply criticized by Valery Turovsky in the magazine “Art of Cinema”, where he pointed out that despite the enormous potential of the script - “a great many plot and thematic branches, among which there are so many important, relevant ones that would be enough for a good five ”, the authors, gaining the trust of the viewer by exploiting the theme of war, which is shown in rare frames, created a meaningless film without “any significant , any mature (not to mention the hard-won) author’s thought

The film tells the story of a disillusioned scientist, whose career and personal life are shattered by betrayal. He undergoes a profound awakening through a of personal losses and self-reflective acts of courage. A young scientist, Bekasov, works at a research institute in Moscow, where his groundbreaking work is stolen by his father-in-law, one of the institute's directors. While everyone knows the work is Bekasov's, they do nothing, and even his wife—loyal to her father—leaves him. He had previously left his first wife and daughter in a small town to marry her. Bekasov begins to solely for himself, shown through a of introspective episodes. However, life forces him to reevaluate his choices: his mother's death, a poignant conversation with his now-grown daughter, and a plea for help from a dying woman all leading to his awakening. The climax occurs when he rushes to meet a woman he loves, defending a stranger on a train from drunkers harass along the way. This brave act marks his full return to empathy and universal values

The Garden" is a comedy feature film directed by Sergei Ovcharov based on the play “The Cherry Orchard" by A.P. Chekhov. The film mainly involves theater actors from St. Petersburg (with the exception of Igor Yasulovich). 1904 The beautiful garden of the landowner Lyubov Andreevna Ranevskaya will soon be sold for debts. Lopakhin offers Ranevskaya the only way out - to divide the land into plots and rent them out to summer residents. The inhabitants of the estate spend their time idly, discussing possible plans to save the garden. There is no money to buy the garden at auction in order to divide it into plots for dachas. The former inhabitants of the estate are no longer needed by anyone and are leaving in all directions. The film script did not include the entire text of the play, Ovcharov used ideas from Chekhov's unwritten works, sketches of which were preserved in notebooks. The Shining World" is a 1984 Soviet wide-screen film based on the novel of the same name and stories by Alexander Green, directed by Bulat Mansurov. In the circus of the city of Zurbagan, a mysterious stranger suddenly appears - Drood, who has the ability to fly. Many are present at this performance, but only a few people think about what is happening: the clown Arsi, the secular beauty Runa and her father Saddi Daugavet, a billionaire, the secret ruler of the country. On the orders of the rich man, his brother, the secret police minister Chappie Daugavet, arrests Drood. Suddi tries to find out the secret of the flying man, but he is not at all interested in worldly goods. At the same time, Drood is not burdened by being in prison, but Runa encourages the young man to escape and invites him to meet on a secret island belonging to his father On the way there, the flying man meets the lighthouse keeper Stebbs, from whom he learns about Saddi Daugovet and his cruel experiments. One of these experiences is showing the sunset to the girl Tavi, who had previously been raised in complete darkness for eighteen years

During the Great Patriotic War, the main character of the film, the boy Zhenya, is sent to be evacuated to his grandmother in the Siberian city of Zima. The film by Yevgeny Yevtushenko became the subject of controversy among Soviet critics and found recognition in the West (after an out-of-competition screening at the Venice Film Festival). Film critic Viktor Demin called the film mediocre, while film director Savva Kulish, after watching the film, praised Yevtushenko’s work, wishing him further success. Screenwriter Evgeniy Gabrilovich “supported the poet’s creative.” Speaking about the film, critics agree that “Kindergarten” is difficult “... to compare with the works of leading masters” and that “it is significantly inferior to them in creative terms” (film critic Alexander Fedorov, 1984). At the same time, they note the symbolic and metaphorical nature of the language of screenwriter-director Yevtushenko. Yevtushenko’s work is examined in detail in his book “The Poet of the Russian Fatherland: E. A. Yevtushenko: 1965-1995.” Doctor of Philology, Professor of the Department of Khakass State University Valery Prishchepa. The author examines the ground to the creation of the script and the emergence of the idea for creating the film. He sees the main conflict of the film in the confrontation “child - war”. Prishchepa notes the “intermittent” nature of the plot, characteristic of many of Yevtushenko’s poems. He also compares the film with “Wounded Man” by N. Gubenko, “Introduction” by I. Talankin, “Ivan’s Childhood” by A. Tarkovsky

Afterword" is a 1983 Soviet film directed by Marlen Khutsiev based on the story “The Father-in-Law Has Arrived" by Yuri Pakhomov. The duet of Rostislav Plyatt and Andrei Myagkov presents a dramatic situation: an old man who comes to visit his daughter and son-in-law is faced with the indifference of the children. Alexey Borisovich, a 75-year-old father, comes to Moscow to visit his daughter from the south. But my daughter went on a business trip. The father-in-law is greeted by his son-in-law, who has taken to work on his dissertation. Two representatives of different generations and views on life spend several days together. Alexey Borisovich, a former military surgeon, while waiting for his daughter, while away the time talking with his son-in-law Vladimir, periodically meeting with old friends and walking around Moscow, where he spent his pre-war youth. son-in-law notes to himself the old man’s unusual childish enthusiasm for any reason, which strangely irritates him. One spring evening there was a thunderstorm, which brought the old man into indescribable delight. He was so excited that Vladimir even took several photographs of his father-in-law against the drop of an open window. The day, Vladimir’s work doesn’t go well; The old man tells his son-in-law that he clearly. doesn't like his job and that he should get rid of unnecessary things in his office and take up exercise to improve his productivity

At the height of the holiday season in Crimea, the film of “The Flying Dutchman” leaving for an expedition to the desert leaves the fake wooden ship “Fortuna” on the seashore for the preservation of a local resident - former captain Vasily Kuchkin, whose wife performs unique genetic experiments on plants. Contrary to the director’s prohibition, the captain, succumbing to the persistent persuasion of the “savage” vacationers, allows them to on the ship. One of the vacationers, an amateur astronomer, brought with him a telescope with which he observes a comet approaching the Earth. At the same time, mysterious and mystical events are taking place inside the ship, actually caused by an experimental robot locked in one of the cabins. On television, scientists announce the possibility of a comet falling to Earth, in the sea near a resort town, which could cause a giant tsunami. Panic begins among the masses of vacationers; the beach quickly becomes empty. When the approaching comet becomes visible in the sky during the day, the “savages” living on the ship decide to urgently leave, but the road from the city is blocked by a rock slide. They return and try to escape on a fake ship by pushing it into the water with their cars, but it breaks into two parts, one of which floats out to sea with two people. The English town of Newlingham near London, shortly after the end of the First World War. The wealthy Conway family celebs the coming of age of their daughter Kay, which brings together all the children of the recently widowed Mrs. Conway. The war is over, everyone is full of bright hopes: Maege is going to fight for social justice and hopes to involve family friend Gerald in this, Kay is going to become a famous writer, the youngest Carol dreams of becoming an actress, and everyone predicts a successful marriage for the beautiful Hazel. His mother's favorite and war hero Robin is going to go into business, and even the mattress Alen is expected to make a career in the civilian field. Gerald brings aspiring entrepreneur Ernest Beavers to the house, who awkwardly crumples his hat in his hands. 18 years pass. Members of the Conway family gather in the house again - except for Carol, who has already died. The reality turned out to be harsher than it seemed many years ago. Kay is forced to pursue journalism; Maige remained an old maid, and the top of her dreams was the position of head of the gymnasium; Alain remained a minor municipal employee, still living with his mother; Hazel was forced to marry Beavers, whom she did not even want to pay attention to in her youth; and Robin safely squandered the money that Mrs. Conway, who had unlimited faith in her son, gave him, and as a result, unpleasant financial issues now need to be urgently resolved. Beavers can help, but he sharply refuses to do so, and Mrs. Conway slaps him in the face, after which Ernest leaves the house. His wife follows him. Without really deciding anything, the family members disperse, leaving only Alain and Kay, who, in a conversation with her brother, remarks: “There is an evil spirit in the world, which we call Time.” Then the action returns : the family holiday continues, and the viewer, through the eyes of Kay, who saw the future, can discern the beginnings of conflicts, the continuation of which she has just learned

Victory" is a Soviet two-part feature film directed by Evgeny Matveev, filmed in 1984. The literary basis of the film is the novel of the same name by Alexander Chakovsky. The all-Union premiere of the film took place in cinemas on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the Victory, and the television premiere on Central Television a year later, in May 1986. Rental - 20,300,000 viewers (1985, 17th place). The first film is “A Time of Hope...”. The second film is “...Time for Troubles.” In the summer of 1945, during the preparation and holding of the Potsdam Conference, two war correspondents met, the Soviet Mikhail Voronov and the American Charles Bright. Thirty years later they meet again, this time during the 1975 Helsinki European Peace and Security Conference. The film based on the novel by A. Chakovsky “Victory” talks about the confrontation between two worlds - the world of socialism and the world of capitalism. The ideological basis of the film (as well as the novel) is built in full accordance with the realities of the time of creation

Yadgar, a tram driver and the son of a tram driver, meets Asal, who is lost in the capital of the Uzbek SSR, and falls in love with her. Coincidentally, this happens on the eve of the matchmaking planned by his family - the family wants him to get married before serving in the army. Yadgar invites Asal to spend the night on his veranda, and the day they find her aunt’s house together. Asal, looking at those around her, tries to imitate the girls around her, gets a new hairstyle, and this attracts attention that she does not like. She gets upset and soon leaves for her native Vuadil. Yadgar follows her. Having received his son's summons, his father, widower Husan, leaves to look for Yadgar. During the course of the film, he is fined for traveling without a ticket (he forgot his service ID at ) by Aunt Asal, whom Husan immediately tries to start courting. Akhmad, a policeman and Asal’s father, opposes the relationship between the young people; he proposes to resolve this issue in a public duel during a big holiday. Both fathers believe that they can make their children happy by giving in, and in the end the fight ends in a draw. Young people spend time together while the family argues about how to organize the wedding. Husan meets Halima, discovers that she is Ahmad's sister, and the families eventually decide to have two weddings. At the end of the film, the family sees off Yadgar at the airport for his military service

The Fairies' Autumn Gift" is a Soviet fairy tale film based on the fairy tale “Galoshes of Happiness" by Hans Christian Andersen. Filmed at the Belarusfilm studio in 1984. The kind, but, alas, short-sighted Fairy of Happiness, contrary to the warnings of the more experienced Fairy of Sorrow, gave young Freken magic galoshes that grant wishes. Happiness came to young Freken and her friends - they found themselves in what they loved. But the fulfillment of their desires did not make other people, who received galoshes during the course of the plot, happy because of the laziness, callousness and bitterness of their hearts. The first literary script of the film was approved in March 1978, the second and final - in July with the general approval of the Belarusfilm artistic council. The start of work directly on the tape was then postponed for a long time. 1980, but at the insistence of studio director Evgeniy Voitovich, another film was shot instead - “The Commander’s Daughter,” which combined children’s and military-patriotic themes

The owner, feeling sorry for his niece, refuses, but the matchmakers force him to agree to the marriage, threatening to make the family secret public

Road Check" is a 1971 Soviet war film, the independent directorial debut of Alexei German. The script by Eduard Volodarsky is based on the story “Operation Happy New Year!” by Yuri German (the director’s father) about a Russian collaborator who voluntarily surrendered to Soviet partisans in order to atone for his guilt for going over to the enemy’s side. The film “Operation Happy New Year!”, shot in 1970, went “on the shelf” because Goskino officials considered the film to de-heroize the people’s resistance to the enemy during the Great Patriotic War. The film was released on the big screen only in 1986 under the title “Road Check” (in the credits the year of filming is indicated as 1985). The filmmakers were awarded prizes at various film festivals, as well as the USSR State Prize. The events of the film take place in December 1942 in the Pskov region occupied by the Wehrmacht. In the rear of the German troops there is a partisan detachment under the command of the former rural district police officer Ivan Lokotkov. Now he is ready to atone with blood for betrayal of the Motherland if they believe him

There are still three hours of flight to the destination, alternate airports are d due to weather conditions, and the remaining two engines, in the opinion of the chief designer and test pilot, will be able to ope at the take-off mode necessary to compensate for the thrust deficit for only 15 minutes. In the process of analyzing the current situation by specialists on the ground, a suspicion arose that in fact there was no engine fire, since none of the crew saw the fire, and the fire alarm panels were falsely activated. due to a technical malfunction in the wiring as a result of an unforeseen combination of circumstances. Fouette (French fouetté, from fouetter - “whip; push; whip”) is a generally accepted abbreviated name for a virtuoso movement of classical dance, performed as a of sequentially repeated rounds at a fast pace and in one place, during which the working leg, at the end of each 360° turn from a bent position, opens exactly to the side (à la seconde, to the 2nd position) to a height 45-90°. There is another, Western technique of execution, in which the working leg performs the rond de jambe en l’air at 45° and higher

Slunce, seno, jahody (Sun, hay, strawberries) is a Czech comedy film made in 1983, usually regarded as one of the classics of the Czech comedy industry. Written and directed by Zdeněk Troška, ​​it was filmed and set in Hoštice, a small rural village in the Czech portion of the former Czechoslovakia. It is a play on the perceived stereotypes of daily life in a village community. A Czech agricultural student, Šimon Plánička, arrives at the small South Bohemian town of Hoštice, and joins the local JZD (agricultural co-op) with the intention of trying out his experiment regarding the "Milk yield of cows in regards to a cultural environment". He runs into difficulty with the directorship of the JZD, but he finds them eager to help once they hear he's the son of the local agricultural commissioner, as his last name is also Plánička. The Timok Rebellion (Serbian Cyrillic: Timočka buna, romanized: Timočka buna) was a popular uprising that began in eastern Serbia (now the region of the Timok Valley) on 28 September 1883, led by the People's Radical Party. It has been called the most important event in Serbia between independence (1878) and the First Balkan War (1912).

“The Man from Capuchin Boulevard” is a 1987 Soviet comedy western directed by Alla Surikova and written by Eduard Akopov. The premiere screening of the film took place on June 22, 1987 at the Leningrad Colosseum cinema at the Mosfilm-87 film festival.

“Accelerator” is a 1987 Soviet eccentric comedy directed by Alexei Korenev and written by Dmitry Ivanov and Vladimir Trifonov. The film was shot by the Creative Association of Comedy and Musical Films of the Mosfilm film studio in the Krasnodar Territory in the fall of 1986.

” - Soviet feature-length color film, shot in 1986 by director Munid Zakirov at the Mosfilm film studio. The film was released at the height of Gorbachev's anti-alcohol campaign and satirically depicts drunkenness and its consequences.
“Forgotten Melody for the Flute” is a 1987 Soviet satirical comedy directed by Eldar Ryazanov based on the script by Emil Braginsky, exposing bureaucracy. Contains elements of psychological drama.

Starman is an American science fiction film by John Carpenter, released in 1984 and produced by Michael Douglas. For this film, Jeff Bridges, who played the leading role, was nominated for the Golden Globe for the first time in his career, was nominated for the Oscar for the third time, and also won the Saturn Award for the first time.

“Plumbum, or a Dangerous Game” is a 1986 Soviet melodrama directed by Vadim Abdrashitov and written by Alexander Mindadze. Filmed by the Third Creative Association of the Mosfilm film studio.

Jaguar" is a 1986 Soviet drama directed by Chilean director Sebastian Alarcón and written by Alarcón and Tatyana Yakovleva, based on the novel “The City and the Dogs" by Mario Vargas Llosa (1963). Filmed by the Fourth Creative Association of the Mosfilm film studio. The film was released in wide release in February 1987. According to the magazine "Soviet Screen", "Jaguar" became one of the box office leaders among Soviet feature released in the first quarter of 1987: during the 12 months of release, the film was watched by 17.4 million viewers. “Interception” is a 1986 Soviet adventure action film, filmed by director Sergei Tarasov at the Mosfilm film studio. The film tells about the struggle between Soviet and American intelligence services.

“The Cry of a Dolphin” is a fantastic feature film directed by Alexei Saltykov, shot at the Mosfilm studio in 1986 based on the book by Nikolai Cherkashin “The Secret of Archelon” (“The Cry of a Dolphin”). The film premiered in April 1987.

” - a Soviet two-part tragicomedy in the genre of fantastic dystopia, filmed by director Georgy Danelia at Mosfilm in 1986. The film had an impact on Russian-speaking culture - fictitious words from the film entered the spoken language, some phrases of the characters became set expressions.
“A Lonely Woman Wants to Meet” is a feature film shot at the Dovzhenko Film Studio by director Vyacheslav Krishtofovich in 1986. Seamstress Claudia is 43 years old, but she is still single.

“Tomorrow There Was War” is a Soviet film based on the story of the same name by Boris Vasiliev, the thesis of VGIK graduate Yuri Kara. A dramatic film story about a generation whose youth fell during the Stalinist repressions and then the Great Patriotic War.

A children's playground is an area where elements of children's outdoor play equipment are located for the purpose of organizing meaningful leisure time. Play equipment, in turn, is a set of structural structures that promote physical and mental development, taking into account individual characteristics and while having a beneficial effect on the social adaptation of the child

The year is 1945, the Great Patriotic War has just ended. Soviet intelligence officer Yuri Sosnin (Alexander Timoshkin) is considered dead and awarded posthumously, but in fact he lost his memory and ended up in the hospital without documents, not remembering who he was and where he came from.

That night, when mer and single mother Anna Smirnova was in a neighboring city on a business trip, a fire broke out in her apartment. Although the damage was minor (only the hallway burned out), her son Alyosha was in the apartment that night and inhaled smoke. They manage to hospitalize him in time, but when he comes to his senses, it is discovered that from nervous shock he has lost the ability to speak and has withdrawn into himself. Anna, however, watching her son, sees: Alyosha was not frightened by the fire, he saw the arsonist. Investigator Tamara Miitina is looking into the case. The experts' results turn out to be more than strange: firstly, the cause of the fire was lit matches, which were scattered in disarray on the floor (but the Smirnovs have no matches in their household); secondly, the door to the apartment was not broken into, the lock was opened with the “original” key. Because of this, Anna herself and her ex-husband and Alyosha’s father Pavel are the first to fall under suspicion. Anna’s alibi on the night of the arson is confirmed by her friend Olga, with whom Anna spends the night on business trips, but Pavel spent that night at the airport and his alibi cannot be confirmed. Anna discovers that a bottle of gift alcohol has disappeared from the apartment and her work ID has disappeared somewhere. In turn, Pavel tells the investigation that he does not have the keys to the apartment, but later it turns out that this is not so. Against the drop of this, Tamara arranges a confrontation with the former spouses, as she wants to clarify several questions about their personal s: it turns out that in the past Pavel had problems with alcohol and several years ago was ed with a drug treatment clinic, and also underwent sanatorium treatment for alcoholism, and a year after that, for some reason, he and Anna divorced, citing irreconcilable differences. However, Tamara sees that the reason for the divorce was something else, but the Smirnovs categorically avoid answering

The personal belongings of the leader of a group that tried to organize a provocation on the western border fall into the hands of security officers. This is the former cornet general Turchin (prototype - Yurko Tyutyunnik).

Sam Page, former fascist mercenary Semyon Paigin, and Western intelligence agents Mart and Goodwin are trying to find and hide secret Gestapo archives. However, their plans are disrupted by a group of State Security officers led by Major Alexei Stolyarov, who are conducting an operation to neutralize the agents and seize the archives.

The Head of the Gorgon" is a Soviet color feature film on the theme of the Civil War in Russia, filmed in 1986 by director Yuri Mastyugin from a script by Victor and Valentina Ponomarev at the film studio named after. Gorky. After falling into the hands of bandits, former Red Army soldier Svetlov learns about a counter-revolutionary conspiracy in which the Socialist Revolutionaries and monarchists participate. With the help of the security officers, he neutralizes Konar's gang and uncovers a conspiracy in which Lena's sister, Gorgon, is involved. Ultimately, the security officers eliminate the conspirators, defeat the rebellion, and Svetlov goes on a new mission, accompanied by Lena Lukonina

I Believe in Love" is a Soviet feature film filmed by Elena Mikhailova at the Mosfilm studio in 1986. Sequel to the film "The Boy From Our Town" (1942). The Lukonin family s a quiet life, but soon they have to face secrets from the past. It turns out that their two children - Alexey and Konstantin - are adopted and were rescued during the Great Patriotic War. A meeting with their real mother, Anna Mikhailovna, changes the family’s life forever. The work of the director of the film, E. Mikhailova, is guilty of outright unprofessionalism. At the same time, the “beneficiaries” found themselves in a more advantageous position than the young performers - many years of experience helped. The “self-direction” did not fail in the episodes where the sharply dramatic conflict between Varvara Andreevna, who raised two adopted sons, and their natural mother (L. Sokolova), who lost her children during the war, was played out. The feelings of women are conveyed by the actresses as deeply personal, tragically experienced... V. Kandelaki’s portrayal of Vano, a devoted friend of the Lukonin family, is still wise and bright. It was much more difficult for the artists A. Goloborodko, V. Titova, L. Zakharova, V. Izotova, M. Yakovlev, E. Valyushkina. they had to act at their own peril and risk, playing out the love troubles and all sorts of meetings and partings that were not very impressively thrown up by the script. In the lyric-epic saga about the Lukonin family, it was necessary to combine two layers of life - past and present. But fragments from the film “The Boy From Our Town” never fit into the image of today’s heroes. Why The point, of course, is not the film - once black and white, but now? color. Episodes from the unaged film by Alexander Stolper and Boris Ivanov refute the aesthetics of the current film

The Lynx Returns" is a Soviet feature film. Continuation of the “The Path of Selfless Love" and “The Lynx Takes the Path.” The tetralogy is dedicated to the memory of Vitaly Bianchi. The film is directed against poachers who predatorily exterminate the animal world. The forester Mikhalych (Dmitry Orlovsky) saves a little lynx from poachers, and over time he grows into a real guard lynx, but poachers decide to settle to Mikhalych and his numerous menagerie and, wanting to get the skins of valuable animals, they kill the forester. The lynx is inherited by the new forester Yuri Ivanovich Drozdov (Alexander Mikhailov), who patiently accustoms the animal to himself. The role of a lynx named Kunak was played by a male lynx named Vaska; in the 1990s, when he was already about twenty years old, he was donated by Mosfilm to the then created Ivanovo Zoo, where he d for another ten years, becoming a symbol of the zoo - depicted on its logo

” is a 1986 Soviet feature film in wide format and widescreen, shot by Nikolai Mashchenko at the A. Dovzhenko film studio according to his own script, written together with Ivan Drach.

Sovereign Emperor Alexander Pavlovich, together with his faithful Cossack ataman Platov, came to London after the war of 1812. The British are trying to win the tsar over to their side with “various tricks,” but Platov says that in Rus' they are doing no worse. Alexander left and died a few months later, leaving the flea with priest Fedot. His brother, who followed him to the throne, Emperor Nicholas I, nicknamed “Palkovich,” orders Platov to go and look for craftsmen who will do the job better than an English flea. The chieftain finds them, but since the flea stops dancing after work, Platov scolds the craftsmen who shoed the flea and takes with him Lefty, who made nails for the flea, without leaving him a document. As it turns out, the Tula craftsmen did a very delicate work that needs to be examined through a microscope. It turns out that they shod the flea on all their legs with tiny horseshoes, which is why it doesn’t dance. When the emperor figures everything out, he orders Lefty to be given the best dress and sends him abroad. The British are trying in every possible way to lure the master into their service. During a visit to the British rifle arsenals, Lefty sees that the British do not clean their guns with bricks, and asks to be sent in order to warn the Russian military leadership about this. But on the way to the Solid Earth Sea, he drinks with the ship’s skipper, catches a severe cold and upon arrival, for lack of documents, is sent by the city authorities to the public Obukhvinsk hospital. On the way there, he dies of pneumonia, having managed to tell the policeman: “Tell the sovereign that the British don’t clean their guns with bricks; Let them not cleanse us either

A certain Vasily Pozdnyshev, a respected and noble man in society, a loving husband and a caring father, decides to share with a random fellow traveler on the train how he turned out to be a brutal murderer of his wife, suspecting her of treason. In a fit of jealousy, he stabs her with a Damascus blade.

Only I knowRating 6.1 out of 106.11986, drama, 0+A peculiar journey into the past of a famous architect, the head of a workshop, who once committed a “daring” act: contrary to the opinion of scientists, he defended his own project of a “city on soil.” However, tragedy happened - and the first multi-story building under construction collapsed.

The film was shot in the genre of industrial drama, popular in the 1980s, where two types of managers confront each other - the innovator and the retrograde. At the same time, despite the disagreements and differences in views, the opponents are similar in one thing: each of them is a true professional, dedicated to his work. USSR, 1986. In Leningrad, a fire broke out on a bus on one of the streets. Valery Petrovich Kropotov, director of a large Leningrad production association, helps one of the bus passengers, gives a ride to a young lady in his company car and insistently offers to meet her. The love affair of 60-year-old Kropotov with divorced 35-year-old Valya, who maintains a relationship with the father of her son Karandin, an engineer at the Kropotov production association, gradually unfolds. Kropotov does not tell his wife and daughter about his love affair, or about problems at work, and does not particularly delve into the problems of his own family. Together with the director of a related enterprise, Savitsky, on the Red Arrow train, Kropotov arrives on call in Moscow, to the ministry, where he learns about a possible merger of his enterprise with Savitsky’s enterprise. Wanting to maintain independence, Kropotov promises the deputy minister to commission a high-tech robotic line within a year. Having secured the support of the deputy minister, the Kropotov production association begins work on the project. Kropotov demands that his deputy Yusov and party organizer Antonov begin shock work, but work on the old machines is not going well. Rembetiko (Greek: Ρεμπέτικο) is a 1983 film directed by Costas Ferris and written by Costas Ferris and Sotiria Leonardou, with original music by Stavros Xarchakos. The film is based on the life of rebetiko singer Marika Ninou and gained cult status in Greece. This musical sweeps dramas through a turbulent 40 years in popular singer Marika's (Sotiria Leonardou) life – and in the history of Greece – starting with the singer's birth in Smyrna, Asia Minor in 1917. Marika was deported to Greece along with all the other Greeks in Smyrna when she was seven years old, and a few years later, her parents started a career as a musician and a singer in a nightclub/bar. In the short space of one decade, Marika witnesses her father murder her mother, runs away from , has a baby, and comes to the nightclub to sing in an act with a childhood friend, Yorgos and a bouzouki player, Babis. Success finally comes at the expense of the suicide of another female singer at the club (named Rosa), but then Yorgos is exiled for political reasons, and she and Babis leave for other venues. Although Marika carries a torch for Babis, their relationship never seems to work out, and after many years and World War II go by, she sends her daughter away to a convent school (to later become a dancer in a cabaret, much to Marika's chagrin) and goes on a tour in America. She then returns to Greece to find herself supplanted by a younger singer named Matina who has caught the attention of Babis. Near the end of the movie, she is stabbed in the stomach the night of her reunion concert. Marika dies of her wounds and is buried by the people she sang with as they sing in her memory at the cemetery. There have been hypotheses that the story is based on the life of Marika Ninou with Babis playing the part of Vasilis Tsitsanis. However, there are glaring differences between the film and the real life of Marika Ninou

"Crocodile Dundee" is a 1986 Australian-American action comedy film set in the Australian outback and New York City. The film stars Paul Hogan as Mick Dundee himself, for whose performance the actor received a Golden Globe award, and Linda Kozlowski as reporter Sue Charlton.

The Ballad of Narayama (楢山節考, Narayama Bushikō) is a 1983 Japanese film by director Shōhei Imamura. It stars Sumiko Sakamoto as Orin, Ken Ogata, and Shoichi Ozawa. It is an adaptation of the book Narayama bushikō by Shichirō Fukazawa and slightly inspired by the 1958 film directed by Keisuke Kinoshita. Both explore the legendary practice of ubasute, in which elderly people were carried to a mountain and abandoned to die. Imamura's film won the Palme d'Or at the 1983 Cannes Film Festival. The film is set in a small rural village in 19th century Japan. According to tradition, once a person reaches the age of 70, he or she must travel to a remote mountain to die of starvation, a practice known as ubasute. The story concerns Orin, who is 69 and in sound health. However, she notes that a neighbor had to drag his father to the mountain, so she resolves to avoid clinging to life beyond her term. She spends a year arranging all the affairs of her family and village, severely punishing a family hoarding food and helping her younger son lose his virginity. The film contains harsh scenes depicting the brutal conditions faced by the villagers. Interspersed between episodes in the film are brief vignettes of nature—birds, snakes, and other animals hunting, watching, singing, copulating, or giving birth

Kolyun, to convince him that there is no need to drink anymore. However, Kolyun at first does not pay attention to Friend, he only wonders how he to him without opening his mouth. But he forces Kolyun to exercise, go for morning runs, and stop drinking. Willy-nilly, Kolyun slowly stops drinking. He talks to him, although disagreements often arise between them. Kolyun was an intelligent man, played the accordion, and achieved great success in this matter, was married, has a seven-year-old daughter living with her mother, still a young and beautiful woman. The heroine, Red Army commissar Klavdiya Vavilova (Nonna Mordyukova), got used to the harsh life of a man during the war. An unexpected pregnancy terrifies her. Having found herself in the family of a poor Jew with many children, Efim Magazannik (Rolan Bykov), she gradually thaws out, but forced to leave her newborn son to the Magazannikov couple, she ultimately returns to the Red Army as a commissar. There are several storylines in the film. The film takes place during perestroika in the USSR in a big city (Leningrad), in a cold winter. The heroes of the film are residents of an ordinary house that is about to fall apart, if not for the heroic efforts of the chief engineer of the housing office, Lagutin. The elevator has not been working for a long time, there is a dangerous crack running through the main wall, the roof has sagged under the weight of snow, but the house continues to stand, literally on the shoulders of the ascetic Lagutin. His wife Maya is visited by her father Satybaldy Kerbabaevich Kerbabaev from the rural out of Central Asia. The first thing he draws Lagutin’s attention to is the fountain of water in the yard from a damaged heating pipe. The old land reclamation worker, a participant in the construction of the Karakum Canal, who has d all his life in the desert, has no idea why in this strange city they are so indifferent to water leakage. There is no one to explain this to the old man, because he hardly understands and does not speak Russian. Lagutin arranges for Kerbabaev to work for him at the housing office. His simple duties include going down to the basement of the house several times a day and checking whether the pipes are leaking, and immediately informing his son-in-law about the presence of a leak. However, as soon as the old man gains control of the water to fix the leak, he immediately shuts off the pipes and locks himself in the basement of the house, refusing to turn on the water. As a result, the heating stops working. Defending Lagutin from his superiors, his assistant declares turning off the hot water an “economic experiment”, after which fame comes to Lagutin. Wanting to expand the “experiment,” the electrician cuts off the power to the house. The ending of the film is a complete phantasmagoria. Residents of the house go outside, light fires, warm themselves, dance and have fun as best they can. They try to fix the electricity themselves and suddenly launch the dead elevator into the winter night sky like a rocket. The culprit of the events, Satybaldy Kerbabaev, sits inside the elevator. The elevator takes him into the unknown

Shock (from the French choc - blow, push) is a pathological process that develops in response to the influence of extreme stimuli and is accompanied by a progressive disruption of the vital functions of the nervous, respiratory systems, circulatory system, metabolism and some other functions, the pathomechanism of which is based on a violation of hemodynamics, primarily microcirculation, with the development of tissue hypoxia. In essence, this is a breakdown of neurohumoral regulation and compensatory reactions of the body in response to extreme damage, with a further critical deterioration of the adaptation syndrome under stress

Walking people, also called zahrebetniki or podsusedniki - in Russia of the 16th-18th centuries, a category of the population consisting of free people, not assigned to either the servicemen or the townspeople; These were servants released by their masters, people from captivity and generally not recorded in the scribe and census books. Ashik-Kerib" became the last completed film by Sergei Parajanov (the film, 1990’s “Confession,” was not completed) and the last film of David Abashidze as a director and actor. The film was not released widely. Parajanov presented it at film festivals in the Netherlands, Germany (Munich Film Festival) and Venice. Only after participating in international film festivals was the film given a distribution certificate. In 1988, a representative of the Cannes Film Festival, Robert Favre L'Bray, came to Moscow. He wanted to take the film “Ashik-Kerib” into the competition of the film festival, but the film was not ready by that time. Robert Favre L'Bray was not interested in the other two dozen that were selected and offered to him
